job_title: Wraparound Support Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros: Some of the advantages of working for this agency are their trainings and professional development.
cons: The pay is severely low if you are an hourly employee or do not have a masters degree and license. Management makes it very clear that you are not to ask for any pay increases and that they are not interested changing this pay structure. When you are an hourly employee in the field or in an in person services program, you end up being asked (or just told a lot of the time) to do extensive amounts of work that are well beyond your pay grade and training with no additional compensation. There is an advertised “open door policy” for managers and supervisors however it really depends on the supervisor. The majority of the supervisors do not seem to really care about the needs of barriers faced by employees and are very invested in maintaining the status quo even if it is inequitable. There are a few good supervisors who are really solid scattered throughout the agency, I have only met one supervisor in my time there who was honest, caring, and equitable but I assume there are more. I worked under several different programs in different areas.

review_title: Wonderful and flexible place to wor
pros: I have worked at Seneca for years and absolutely love the people that I work with, both in my department and within other departments all over the agency. Everyone is so friendly and collaborative, and it is nice to be around so many people with similar visions and goals. The work is hard, but it is so desperately needed in the communities we serve. Leadership supports individuals well and encourages employees to take care of themselves when needed. The benefits and pay are pretty decent, but you just can't beat the environment/culture that Seneca staff have created. Depending on what your long term goals are, there are a lot of growth opportunities or just chances to try your hand at different spectrums of social service work.
cons: In any line of profession chosen here, the work is challenging and not always immediately rewarding so you need to make sure you are here for the right reasons and know what your motivation is for working with this population that we serve.

review_title: All that glitters is not gold
pros: The mission, the kids, the staff
cons:
Seneca cares more about public perception than quality of services or treatment of staff and clients. Senior Leaders pressure programs to have staff give positive reviews on this website and others - anything to keep up appearances instead of listen to what's wrong and try to make a difference. 

I was hopeful for changes with the CEO change - more transparency, less overt protection of toxic behavior from Senior Leaders, fair HR practices. Instead, the agency is moving in a corporate direction - the c-suite (Chief level) consists of Woke-speaking white leaders who are mandating changes without input. Standing on the backs of black and brown staff and leaders while preaching DEI to anyone who will listen.

cons: obsessed with "anti racist" and "dismantling white supremacy" jargon but doesn't really make sense because if that was truly the mission the school wouldn't exist. if we couldn't handle a student's behaviors we'd call the police and its hard to feel supportive of the students when thats the protocol. should've reopened school in phases, didn't give clear answers regarding reopening and caused a lot of stress among staff that work directly with families and students, too many committees that talk about problems that aren't action oriented or cohesive with other programs that make a difference, admin says they're open to feedback and barely address the concerns directly or clearly kept doing what they had in mind to do (in regards to larger matters). and basically gave us no choice in disguise of choice or "feedback"

pros: In general, the people at Seneca are kind and easy to work with. I love the work Seneca does for our clients and appreciate their efforts to make an impact. Being part of something that makes an actual difference is something I’m proud of.
cons: Seneca’s leadership consistently undervalues and dismisses our QA department. It’s disappointing considering that Seneca promotes equity however that initiative is sorely missed internally, specifically for the QA managers. People are often surprised by the scope and depth of our responsibilities and more shocked to find that the pay isn’t reflective of that. It’s clear that HR doesn’t grasp our role and level of involvement in multiple programs and regions either based on the inexcusable reasons we’ve been told why our pay is so low in comparison to other supervisors. Supervisors’ pay in other departments reflect their workload and responsibilities; it would be equitable for the same to apply to QA. We understand that we’re a nonprofit agency but if they can compensate others fairly with our budget, why continuously exclude QA managers? As a department and in individual supervisions, we’ve talked about this issue SEVERAL times. Some in QA have had the exact conversation for YEARS, others have just left since the leadership won’t prioritize us and/or provide an equitable solution. It’s demoralizing. This mistreatment has even discouraged many Health Information Specialists (our supervisees) from pursuing a leadership role in QA. They do not want to be taken advantage of especially considering that the pay doesn’t justify it. A QA managers’ normal workload, even excluding covering for vacant positions and doing OT, deserves to be financially recognized and compensated for.

pros: Nice coworkers and decent benefits..
cons:
You are expected to do a TON of extra work that isn’t part of your job description for low pay and no raises, at least if you’re an admin staff. Doesn’t matter if your workload increases dramatically, admin staff, especially QA managers, are not compensated fairly. You will cover vacant positions without compensation. I don’t accept the “we’re a nonprofit” excuse when the agency bends over backwards to pay clinical staff well and to give them raises. The number of times clinical staff were given raises in comparison to admin is concrete proof. It just happened again within the past month or so. How demoralizing and demeaning. Stop saying Seneca values equity when you know that’s not true otherwise the pay and experiences of so many in QA would indicate otherwise. Also Seneca deems QA managers as milieu supervisors basically as their excuse to
pay us less than program supervisors or just to avoid paying us better in general. We help manage SEVERAL programs whereas a program supervisor oversees one. The QA department is not clearly defined as a strategy to allow the agency and programs take advantage of our role. Seneca leadership will consistently talk about holding boundaries yet provide no support to QA in this manner, they need our roles to be vague and flexible to ensure someone can pick up any extra work. You’ll be part of many conversations where they say they’re trying to advocate for QA… yet, everyone in QA knows it’s a lie. No one believes the leadership is really trying. It’s something we’re told to pacify us and to make us feel seen. Several leaders acknowledged this has been an issues for years so then why didn’t they actually do anything? I’m doubtful that our new CEO cares either based off our meeting with her. We want action or the truth, spare us all the talk.

review_title: Great Learning Experiences; Not Set Up to Keep You Long Term
pros: Working with Seneca will really help you cut your teeth in the field of crisis management.  Having worked there for over 5 years, I left feeling very equipped to handle things that make a lot of other therapists nervous (CPS reports, police involvement, high levels of self-harm and suicidal/homicidal ideation, clients who are in intense emotional pain and at the mercy of broken systems which can make them violent and highly resistant).  The kids and families will draw you in (they are AMAZING), and the staff will make you stay.  They hire wonderful people - for the most part.  Also, a great place to get your hours and they are very supportive in getting people licensed.  If you find a speciality and want to get trained in it, it's likely they will pay for part or all of the training. If you are interested in moving up to supervisor and administrator roles, you can do that pretty quickly (within 5-6 years if you start unlicensed) and they are good about hiring within.  They have pretty excellent health benefits and the vacation is really good, too.  Pay is average for this work, so that means it's pretty low in my opinion, but no worse than anywhere else.  Some of the administrative teams really do appreciate their staff and try to show you with food and gift-cards and things. It's a good place if you want something fast-paced where you want to learn how to support youth in their darkest days, but expect to burn-out within a few years.
cons: It's a non-profit, so every position really feels like 2-3 jobs.  Hard to set firm boundaries to keep a work-life balance, especially now that things are remote, but some people are better at it than others (I was not good at this). My biggest issue is the lack of specialization and the way they seem to be more focused on expanding their presence rather than creating innovative programs.  This is not the place to really learn how to do structured therapy (CBT, DBT, ACT, EMDR, etc. They're just like: this is what trauma can look like.  Now go keep these kids from killing themselves and each other.) I think they might have been ground-breaking when they were established in the '80s, but now a lot of the programs feel like they are feeding into the problematic systems which keep their clients marginalized and dependent on this kind of support.  They talk a big game about being "woke," and they hire plenty of POCs for introductory positions, but it feels like there's a lot of prejudice and racially influenced decisions going on in staffing the upper management.  The CEO (who you will meet and see around) has a good heart but he's been too removed for too long from the reality of the work, and from the lives of his employees.  All the highest up positions need an overhaul, as does the mission and focus of the agency, in my opinion.

review_title: An amazing place to work - each and every day is filled with opportunity and a chance for growth.
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Fremont, CA
pros: Seneca strives on an unconditional care model – a belief that each an every child will be offered continuous therapeutic support regardless of the behaviors that brought them into the program in the first place. My experience with Seneca has been nothing less than that. Day in and day out, there are individuals here that work incredibly hard to be patient during crisis situations, understanding of multicultural backgrounds, all while being thoughtful in using extremely individualized interventions for each and every child. At Pathfinder Academy in Fremont, we work with a variety of children – from children that are diagnosed with Pervasive Developmental Disorders, Oppositional Defiance Disorders, to others who are diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and more.  Regardless of clinical diagnoses, there are therapists, classroom counselors, teachers, and school administrators that work collectively as a team to provide structure and care so that they can meet their academic and behavioral goals.  I’m truly thankful to Seneca for allowing me the opportunity to cultivate my skills, and direct my passion and empathy in a field where multiple lives are being enriched. Working with Seneca you may find that no two days are exactly the same, but every day is filled with opportunity and a chance for growth.
cons: This job can be challenging, both physically and emotionally however there are many supportive faces that can coach you through stressful times (just ask!). It’s important to find a balance between the job that we do, and the personal lives we live – and it can be a struggle to find that balance. It's important to continue finding creative and fun ways to care for your self! :)

job_title: Family Support Counselor (SF Wrap) in San Francisco, CA
pros: I absolutely loved my coworkers and my clients in the community. I learned some useful things both through trainings and through getting to do certain things on the ground (mental health interventions, working with therapists and schools, etc). These things earn the three stars I gave Seneca.
cons: Management was poor, promising to be responsive but not delivering. Constant turnover. The paperwork requirements were ridiculous and almost nobody reached quota. This was a huge point of stress and instead of acknowledging that expectations were too high (driving all day every day, doing daily paperwork, monthly meetings, weekly client visits, crisis management, etc , etc)plus working for one weekend day AND one weekend day on call once a month, management continued to tell us to do our paperwork "or else" (as in the organization would suddenly go under). Many people worked consistent overtime that they didn't include on their timecard just to be able to write paperwork and document enough percentage of their forty hour week. I am honestly shocked that Seneca has so many good reviews. I felt pretty defeated when I left as did many others and was totally burned out on social work. So many promises to change and to improve self-care opportunities for staff, and none were met. Pay is WAY too little for the amount of fatigue you will feel and the amount of stress. A lot of talk with no follow through.

review_title: Unconditional Care doesn't stop at the children and families.
pros:
I took a position at Seneca a few months after I graduated from college. I was green to the field and more importantly green to the professional scene. Throughout my time at Seneca, I worked with some amazing people. Teams filled with compassionate, talented, motivated and truly dedicated people. 
I learned so much from everyone I came in contact with. Everyone was willing to share their experiences with me and the training offered, always put me in good stead and built up my confidence.

After 3 years in my role, I was promoted to an administrative position where I was able to test my gained skills. I loved the opportunity for growth within the company that allowed me to challenge myself in new ways. 
The people at Seneca truly care. They care about your growth, your path in the company, your work life balance and they just truly care about you as much as they care about the children and families they serve. 

-  The people care.
- Trainings are always there for you to be better.
- You can directly see your influence in the company.
- Managers care about your work-life balance and encourage self-care to avoid burnout. 
- You feel like a key part of something bigger than you.
- You will work with some of the coolest people you will ever meet.
cons:
-It's a non-profit, we do this for the work and not the pay but sometimes you can feel the pinch.
-There should be more non-traditional/clinical paths for growth through the agency.
-More focus on effective diversity and inclusion initiatives.

pros: Seneca practices a culture of feedback, training, and sensitivity around mental health and self-care. I really appreciate how understanding management is of needing to take time for yourself for self care outside of work, especially if you work with the children and youth directly. Seneca also has a great training plan in which it invests two weeks for each employee for an agency-wide training that trains employees on Seneca values, history, and culture. They teach that Seneca values and practices Unconditional Care, meaning we don't discharge clients due to "difficult behavior" like other agencies might. Our practices are backed up by studies and statistics and I really appreciate the thoughtfulness of the agency. They also give their employees decent benefits compared to other for-profits and non-profits alike.
cons: Compensation could be a little better. Although we are a non-profit, I believe the employees deserve better compensation for the hard and meaningful work they do at Seneca. Also, each site has a different culture and community of people, meaning the Seneca mentality of inclusivity and community-building isn't as strong in some sites as others. I'm sure this is just a byproduct of having a growing organization and it being more difficult to have consistent work culture across many different locations.

pros: The kids and families we work with are amazing! Although the work is difficult, supporting this population and bearing witness to their resilience every day reminds me why I still do this work. Seneca does an amazing job of hiring brilliant, compassionate, and dedicated individuals. My Seneca colleagues are some of the best people I have ever met! Additionally, this agency is one of the only places in our region that pays a living wage and offers decent benefits to unlicensed mental health professionals gaining hours toward licensure.
cons: Run away (and fast) from this agency if you are an unlicensed Clinician wanting to gain solid clinical skills that translate to other types of work and hope to practice ethically. The training and supervision necessary to gain these skills is not a priority for the agency. Run even faster if you are a licensed mental health professional- there is no place for you in this agency, as demonstrated by the fact that very few people in upper management actually have these credentials.  In my experience, the agency (at least in my region) is more interested in pleasing and appeasing county partners than they are in delivering quality care to youth and families.

job_title: Quality Assurance Manager in Tustin, CA
pros:
This agency has an inspirational mission statement that rings true in each of its departments and programs. The investment in quality improvement and qualified, happy staff all help make the already-amazing services even more extraordinary. Families and children come first above all else- they way it should be! 

Seneca has a seasoned philosophy and works hard to make sure that they are growing with the times, technology, and most importantly, with the needs of the clients. 

Seneca offers a wide variety of trainings to help professional therapists, teachers, and other staff develop their careers, and even earn CEU's. The agency also offers a scholarship program for staff who want to pursue higher education degrees or even learn another language, all of which contribute to even better services for the clients.

The culture at Seneca is remarkably fun and happy, despite the often serious and heavy daily struggles that go hand-in-hand with working with underserved populations and emotionally disturbed, at-risk youth. Because of the agency focus on self-care and support, as well as direct feedback, openness and levity, there is a decidedly healthy and functional environment for staff and clients to enjoy. It is so rare for a company this large to make its investment in the work so genuine and prevalent in each sector.

I love that Seneca has a tendency to promote from within. What a great opportunity to have been hired in the first place - on top of that, employees can look forward to steady growth and supportive supervisors!
cons: Imagine if Seneca could become a nationwide agency and bring this amazing work to other parts of the country!

pros:
First and foremost on a selfish level, Seneca has been a wonderful employer to me. Starting in an entry-level role with little other work experience (and none in the non-profit/social services sector), I have learned a huge amount and had the opportunity to work closely with an interdisciplinary team of direct service providers (support counselors, clinicians, occupational therapists, etc) and administrative staff. This was the perfect position for me, given the chance it presented to get a sense for many different viable career path options. Informal interviews with co-workers for my first year on the job helped me to narrow my focus to the career path I am on now within Seneca. Every step of the way, Seneca has supported my professional growth, even hiring me into my dream job recently and providing a professional development scholarship to build my skills in that area.

The selfish reasons to work for Seneca are important for any prospective employee to know; the agency's mission to improve outcomes for children and families speaks for itself! Each day of work has a purpose.
cons: This isn't the ideal workplace for folks looking for a routine, 9-5 desk job.  Seneca will respect any boundaries that staff set for their own self-care, but this requires initiative on the part of the employee since our model, Unconditional Care, is very much "do whatever it takes". Working with kids and families to creatively meet their needs means being flexible as to what each work day will bring - even for operations/administrative positions.

pros: Training flexibility colleagues clients benefits

pros: Seneca has been my home since college and I couldn't be happier to be a part of the Seneca family. I was only planning to stay a year but was so moved by the strength of the kids we work with and the commitment of my coworkers that I changed my career path. Since day one I have been provided opportunities that have challenged me and helped me grow, including when I was supported in working part-time during graduate school. Everyone in the agency is so passionate about their jobs and doing the best we can for the families and teams we work with. The best part of the work for me is knowing that I am doing something that matters and that not only makes a difference to the kids and families we work with directly but also contributes to a larger narrative about what is possible for kids and families facing the most difficult challenges. I'm really proud to work at Seneca.
cons: Given the complex challenges that the agency addresses, there is always more work that can be done - whether it be directly with kids and families or at administrative level. Given that everyone is so motivated and committed, it can be difficult to maintain a work-life balance. Management is well aware of this, however, and provides significant support for staff around the emotional impact of the work and figuring out boundaries that work best for each staff.

review_title: Great Organization that Makes a Difference

pros: I have had the opportunity to experience several of Seneca's programs and have been amazed every time. Each program offers its own unique spin on providing children and families with the most effective services possible, but all the programs were the same in that they housed intelligent, dedicated, giving staff who strive to provide the most efficacious service possible while always giving 110%. Seneca's broad scope of services allows families and children to be served that otherwise might not have been able to as they offer many services, including, but not limited to community based services, school services, psychiatric services, residential based services, crisis stabilization services, foster care services, and kinship services. I am humbled each and every day I go to work because I am surrounded by people who have dedicated themselves to supporting and working with some of the most under-served children and families in the community and it makes me proud to be able to give back to communities I grew up in, knowing they are getting the best quality of service possible when they receive services through Seneca! Seneca is the reason I am a better clinician and administrator as I have had several opportunities to grow and advance in my career, starting off as a clinician and now being a director.
cons: I cannot think of any cons I have for Seneca Family of Agencies. Seneca Family of Agencies is an admirable, thoughtful, amazing agency.

pros: Seneca is true to its mission and values unlike many companies out there. And given its size and geography that is a true accomplishment! CEO is an inspiring and real person. Amazing support from management. I feel honored to work with the people I do and get to serve our children and families in times of their greatest need! You really feel like you are part of something different that is making the world a better a place. Once you've had the experience working for different companies you can truly appreciate just how generous Seneca is with its supports and benefits to its employees. 4-5 weeks paid time off is extremely generous! Many of our managers have been in the field for a very long time and have amazing experience that they use to support and develop staff.
cons: With many new programs always starting sometimes that process can be clunky and challenging, but that is to be expected. EHR system is a bit frustrating at times. When you choose to dedicate your career to serving others, work/life balance is always a struggle. Programs further from headquarters can sometimes feel a bit disconnected- but the agency puts efforts to improve this. Sometimes newer staff have trouble knowing the reality of the work they are getting into and can struggle if they don't utilize the support of their supervisors.

review_title: There's no better place to do meaningful work!
job_title: Lead Recruiter in San Leandro, CA
pros: I started my career at Seneca, and this agency has given me more than I could have ever imagined. My coworkers are intelligent, kind, and fun to work with. The agency's culture sets a tone for collaboration and innovation. Best of all, I leave my job every day knowing the work I did matters and makes and immediate impact on the community around me. As a bonus, Seneca's benefits have been stellar and I've been able to plan for my future; I've been the recipient of promotions, mentorship, scholarships and training along the way. Seneca is such an incredible place to find your career and your work family.
cons: Social justice work is challenging and can be fatiguing in nature. It takes deeply dedicated people to undo the work of systems of oppression, and you must be willing to care for yourself and be open to experiencing failure in order to pave a path for success.

review_title: A company that I am proud to be a part of!
job_title: Academic Intervention Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: I have been working for Seneca Family of Agencies in Washington for nearing 6 months now. Within that short time, I have developed a respect for the team that I am partnering with along with great enthusiasm of what is yet to come! As part of an innovative team who strives to support all students, Seneca truly stands behind their values in the educational field. When I was hired as an employee of this agency, I was privileged to visit the headquarters out in California as well as see Seneca in action out in the schools across Oakland and San Francisco. I can't begin to express how impressed I was and how inspired I was as an educator. As a startup team in Washington there are a ton of opportunities for career growth while working for an organization that is committed to its mission of serving all youth.
cons: Being a part of a startup requires patience and flexibility for a "do what it takes" mentality. Sometimes that can stretch you out of your comfort zone and force you to learn a new skill to help support the team.

pros:
There is no doubt in my mind that the people who work for Seneca Family of Agencies are the most exceptional and caring people you may ever meet, let alone meeting a whole staff of these individuals.  When the days get tough (and they get tough) there is always someone there to fall back on for support and understanding similar to a family or a best friend. 

The kiddos are great, sure each one will try you one day ro the next but at the end of the day when they ask you to play tag on the black top, your heart will melt and you'll be reminded of why you work here. They are kids I'll never forget and kids I hope keep smiling into the future.
cons: There is an extremely high turnover rate--so much so that classrooms are almost always understaffed, and a full classroom of staff is celebrated. I worked overtime almost four days ever week, and rarely got to speak with my supervisor due to staffing shortages. In a classroom that was supposed to be staffed by 4 MHAs I often found there were only two of us and we were both stretched pretty thin.

review_title: New employee loving the Seneca experience!
pros: As a new employee, I'd have to say that the hiring process has been very pleasant. The process itself wasn't too lengthy and I always felt informed throughout its entirety. During my initial visits to the office, it was clear that everyone I encountered was passionate about their work. Everyone was so friendly and that translated into the work environment and culture in the office. My mentors have also been very supportive during my training. During the training, they really emphasize open communication between all staff members, which is very important to me. In speaking with some of the staff, there seems to be a lot of opportunities for movement, including movements to other programs within the agency. Another one of the biggest draws, was the MSW program partnership with USC. It's apparent that the agency holds a lot of value for its employees, making it a desirable workplace.  It's refreshing to work amongst such passionate individuals that are genuinely interested in the well-being of their community, co-workers and agency.
cons: I've had little experience with nonprofits, as this is my first position in this sector, but the pay seemed to be low. However, it is understandable given that it is a nonprofit and I knew that when I accepted the job. They do, however, compensate you in other ways, such as PTO (which is pretty generous compared to other agencies/companies.)

job_title: Senior Mental Health Counselor in Hayward, CA
pros:
There are a lot of opportunities for training, mentorship, and varied experience if you look for them and make connections. You can take part in special project to expand your resume, and there are opportunities to move around within the agency.

The kids are inspiring, and the people you get to work with are generally great. You are seen as a person with a life, not just a worker bee (it is easy to get flexible time off, do some paperwork form home if necessary etc.). People really care about what is going on with you.
cons:
There is little communication between different departments, and everyone seems to only want to do what will make them and their department benefit the most. It's a problem of the agency growing faster than it can handle. There is never enough coverage at sites, and it can make doing the work hard.

The work is very draining for relatively little pay; there is a high turn-over rate, which can make your job harder if you do stay longer than other employees. 

There is a strange culture of communication; although feedback is openly encouraged, I have seen evidence to the contrary.

Work-life balance can be difficult.

review_title: A great place to establish roots
pros:
I started as a direct service staff 7 years ago and moved to admin in the last two years so my thoughts cover all my time at the agency. The reasons I have stayed at the agency are:
 
- Important work with amazing kids 
- A strong model of care and set of values that is embodied by staff at all levels of the agency  
- Supportive management that is invested in the success and development of their employees
- Extensive training opportunities that let you explore your interests and support your professional development
- An amazing group of staff that end up being some of your closest friends and are fun people to spend your time with
- A large multi-sector (education, mental health, child welfare, probation) agency that is always growing, making for diverse experiences and promotional opportunities

You're not going to get rich working here, but you will gain the skills you need to be an effective practitioner, make some great friends, and most important - know you are making a big difference to spectacular youth and families that have faced and overcome some unbelievably difficult situations.
cons: Its a nonprofit, so the compensation will never be as much as you could make if you entered the corporate world but that is a given if you choose this line of work.

pros: Core values, They do a lot of good for foster kids.
cons:
From what I've heard, the headquarter and sites are okay to work at,  but if you are thinking of working in the San Leandro administrative office beware. There is a break room but it has been converted to a conference room. So you are expected to take all your breaks and lunches at your desk. My supervisor expected me to work through them, 8.5 hours straight per day. I also wasn't allowed to put the overtime on my timesheet. 

The office is old and hasnt been redecorated since the 1980s. It's unsanitary with dust on the countless boxes that have been piling up over the years. They need to send in a cleaning crew in hazmat suits to clean the moldy kitchen and spiderwebs. Maybe consider vacuuming now and then. 

Company culture was awful,  people don't smile and clearly do not enjoy their jobs. There's a high turn over and those that are long term haven't gotten raises or promotions in years. They are treated worse than volunteers. 

I understand this is a nonprofit but the organization really needs to invest in its employees and offices as much as they claim to do for their community.

review_title: quality care and commitment to standards, only limited by the 24 hour day
pros: The Seneca culture is dedication to safety and collaborative care. The standards by which we are expected to adhere are top notch, and it feels good to be a part of a community that never takes the "easy" route. I get to say I love all of my co-workers and supervisors and who gets to say that?
cons: Finding a work/life balance working with vulnerable families and adhering to high standards can be difficult. It doesn't appear that many of the direct-care positions are geared towards longevity as the salary and retirement options are lower than comparable agencies. That said, I have appreciated the level of transparency about this from the powers that be and made the choice to work here regardless because the other benefits (supervision, licensure support, culture, training) outweighed the concerns. I may feel differently in another 5 years but I'll worry about that then.

review_title: Most staff are great, executive leadership culture is toxic
pros: The people that are attracted to Seneca's mission are incredible. I love collaborating with such thoughtful and compassionate coworkers who will stop at nothing to provide excellent care to youth.
cons: It is an open secret that a small cadre of senior leaders display a lack of the very values the agency claims to care most about. The CEO is the public face of the organization, but in private he does not regard leaders with much respect or empathy, and this trickles down through every level of the organization. The board seems to have no clue that this treatment persists and never once have they asked for feedback as part of the evaluation process, even though feedback is a stated priority agency wide. Meanwhile,  intelligent, passionate leaders leave after being berated or ridiculed - particularly women or minorities as there are sexist and racist overtones to the preferences given to some staff over others.

review_title: The daily steps that are vital to success.
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Seneca's commitment to the individuals and communities they serve is only rivaled by their commitment to employees. The jobs at Seneca require a lot of hard work and dedication but I feel this means all of my coworkers are exceptional people who inspire me to be better everyday. At Seneca I feel proud of the work I do and believe in the mission my organization strives for, however the part of Seneca I love the most is the connection with people. When you work somewhere that values people above all else you feel invaluable.
cons: The hands-on jobs with Seneca are difficult, the population we serve is challenging and the larger systems in power often make our work feel endless. The balance of caring about the work but not being consumed by the often overwhelming gravity of the work is difficult but Seneca spends a lot of time and effort focusing on employee self-care in order to help staff feel supported. Because the agency is a non-profit organization the pay is low and the hours often feel long but I believe it is worth it to feel proud and enjoy the work that I do.

pros: Working at Seneca has been truly rewarding, inspiring, and intellectually stimulating. Its refreshing to work alongside other passionate, progressive, and dedicated individuals. Seneca has been an excellent place to work as a recent MSW graduate working towards my profressional license. Seneca offers a plethora of trainings (licensure trainings and many more) and regular individual and group supervision for ASW/MFTIs. Clinicians also get five weeks of Paid Time Off, and supervisors are generally very supportive of taking the necessary time off to practice self-care due to the often high-stress nature of the job. I am continuously impressed with the innovation of the agency's leadership; rather than work within a limiting system, Seneca identifies areas of need and creates programs to meet these needs. Seneca leaders encourage ideas and feedback from employees, creating an open culture accross the agency.
cons: Some programs at Seneca have managers (generally middle management) who get promoted very quickly and who do not appear to be adequately trained for the challenges of the job. The same can be true (in some programs) with clinical supervisors, who do not always have the range of clinicial knowledge desireable. As a non-profit, the salary for clinicians at Seneca leaves something to be desired, in particular given the rising burden of student loan debt.

pros:
Seneca is an amazing place to work! The agency removes the barriers that so often limit creativity and stifle progress when working in the public sector. Here, if something is right for kids and families - it gets done. Period. 

What's more - the staff is amazing!! There is something about people who are drawn to this work to begin with, but I've worked in other schools and organizations and there's still no comparison between the caliber of people here and the impact that loving your job has on their capacity to be extraordinary.
cons: It's less of a con and more of a disclaimer: the rate of change at seneca is fast. It has to be given the depth of challenge experienced by our clients and the constant threat of underfunding for public services in this country. Even though it's a well-established organization, it always feels a bit like a start-up in this way. That's one of my favorite things about it, but it requires a certain mindset and a whole lot of perspective and self-care.

review_title: Amazing culture of unconditional care and support
pros: As a Support Counselor at Seneca's Intensive Case Management program (ICM) working with probation youth, I have been inspired by the values of unconditional care that have been incorporated by the agency. The collaborative and supportive work environment definitely reassures that you are part of a team and that your voice matters. The clinical supervision and support by colleagues has allowed me to grow tremendously  as a person and as a social worker. In the ICM program, you are able to work closely with various members of the juvenile justice system including probation officers and public defenders, and develop collaborative relationships that allow you to better advocate for and serve our youth. The most rewarding part has been the opportunity to watch our clients grow and overcome their life obstacles through the unconditional care that we provide.
cons: Knowing that this work can be emotionally draining and challenging, self-care is a very important component to staying healthy and being able to continue doing this work. It would be a nice to see more self-care activities for staff incorporated in the workplace during the week. In addition, trainings that address burnout/stress and provide tools for staff to manage these feelings as they come up in this work.

review_title: Org does great work, but needs help in increasing and retaining diverse staff
pros: Flexibility is good. No micro-managing. Ability to move throughout organization is easy. Kudos for attempting to tackle bias practices for hiring and promoting, but saddened to see no real change in the time I was there. (3 years)
cons: Its unfortunate that diversity is really lacking in this organization given the location and population they serve. This is hindered by the higher-ups not appreciating diverse opinion and not really knowing how to support their staff of color. Turnover for staff of color in admin positions is very high, and it isn't hard to see why. There is a very strong clique culture, favoritism is ramped, and although there is a rhetoric of inclusivity, this is seldom practiced. There are issues with communication from the higher-ups trickling down, huge expectations to always work beyond your means, and an air of fakeness that stifles any real representation of personality. Above all the arrogance and pretentiousness that comes with "being the best" is very apparent in any staff that has been there for more than 10 years.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros:
Amazing employees which made coming into work easier, as well as supportive. 
The kids all had various needs, and it truly feels like you are making a difference each day in small ways.
cons: You were not guaranteed a lunch break, or even a ten-minute break when staffing was low. In general, there was a problem with staffing everyday due to people calling out because the job entailed a lot of stress, and not enough room to recuperate the next day especially if you are involved in a lot of physical management which our site had. Sometimes you don't feel supported by your supervisors/individuals who are higher in the company. We voiced our needs continuously in many professional development days (like getting a lunch break, or even a regular 10-minute break) but still did not feel heard. Management will tell you "take your lunch break we will figure it out" yet there is not enough staff on the floor to give you what you need in a stressful moment.

pros: Working in a company that is one of the leaders in mental health for youth is exciting. New programs are being made every couple of months, and the leadership is working hard to improve current and new programs all the time. Every single person that I have met at Seneca is incredibly nice. I was told to expect this before I started at Seneca, but I didn't believe it until I experienced it for myself. They have some sort of system of only hiring the nicest people on the planet. No one is perfect, but you will rarely find as amicable of a staff as the one at Seneca. It may be partly because we have so many therapists... it seems that every other person you meet is trained to be a good listener.
cons: If you are looking to get paid a high salary, this is not the place for you.

review_title: Excellent mission and values, positive culture, strong focus on training and staff development
pros:
Even after twenty years with the agency, I'm still learning and growing.  Seneca stays on the cutting edge of the field, and the agency's size and continual growth offers a steady stream of opportunities for advancement, creativity, and challenge. I love and admire the people with whom I work: their passion, intelligence, positivity, and kindness inspire me everyday and sustain me in both my professional and private life.  

I value the agency's commitment to continual improvement--not only the growth and development of individuals, but also the striving to improve the practices, approaches and culture of the organization itself.  

I'm proud to work for an agency which has earned such a strong and respected reputation for doing important and meaningful work with youth and families.  I'm looking forward to my next twenty years!
cons: At Seneca, we help people who are experiencing tremendous challenges and trying circumstances.  While this work often proves inspiring and invigorating, if can be emotionally challenging and can sometimes leave one feeling depleted.  It is important to develop strong, mutually supportive relationships with team members and to practice excellent self care beyond the workplace.

review_title: Build your skills and take them elsewhere
pros: AMAZING coworkers, flexible schedule (most of the time and depends on position), decent PTO policy although it seems more generous than it actually is because PTO and sick time are combined.
cons: Work/life balance is a major issue, pay is way too low for the Bay Area especially for having a college degree, high turnover, some Managers are great while others have no business in Management, too much expected of Admin staff, and potential to be moved around a lot depending on your program's budget. We keep hearing that pay will increase but nothing has changed. Bachelor-level staff start at only $17.00/hour which is impossible to live on in the Bay Area. We are initially told to hold boundaries and not look at our work phones off the clock, but it is frowned upon if you don't. Admin staff can only promote near central HQ (Oakland and San Leandro) so there isn't a lot of opportunity to grow.

review_title: A growing company with many new opportunities to learn and develop new skills. - Not your typical mental health agency.
pros:
- The Staff: Seneca staff are dedicated, talented, fun and willing to do whatever it takes to help our kids.
- Flexibility: With programs all over the state, there is the possibility to relocate and still work for Seneca.
- Opportunity: Seneca is on the forefront of everything new and innovative, which means there are always new opportunities for professional growth.
- Growth: All the positions I have had at Seneca allowed me to take on a role and utilize my skills to make the position my own while still challenging me to learn new skills along the way.
cons:
- The pay is not that of a for-profit company, but that is to be expected and for me, the feeling of helping others outweighs the difference in wages.
- Administrative roles at Seneca tend to involve taking a lot on and always being flexible to help out where and when it is needed. This is not a problem for me, but it may not be a good fit for everyone.

review_title: I love coming to work every day!
pros:
Seneca hires the best of the best. I truly feel privileged to work alongside the people Seneca hires. I've felt appreciated and valued as Seneca employee, something I rarely felt at my last organization. I'm thankful for the innovative culture, providing ongoing training and pushing me to seek personal growth opportunities. 
The pay is competitive to other nonprofit salaries and the benefits are amazing. I can't say enough good things about this company. I've referred multiple friends to work here. 
I adore the children and families we get to serve at Seneca. Seneca truly is an expert in the field of mental health, foster care, and adoption. I love getting to share when people ask me about the organization I work for.
cons: In the past, Seneca has relied heavily on county contracts for funding which has stunted a culture of philanthropy internally.  For the development staff this has made it arduous to get leadership and staff buy-in with awareness campaigns or fundraising goals. I've seen progress since I've been here but it is a different culture than other nonprofit organizations that hold  individual/private donations as priority.

pros: Even when the work is especially challenging and tough, I feel supported by my colleagues and supervisors. Working with other individuals who enjoy what they do enriches the environment, and makes the hard days easier, and the easier days more fun. There is definitely a sense of team work and collaboration within this agency, which in turn, transpires into the work we do with our youth and families. The work is rewarding knowing that you are making a difference in the community, and there is a feeling of pride that accompanies it. I love working at this agency, and I plan to continue working at this agency for years to come!
cons: The pay is low, as with any social services nonprofit. The agency doesn't provide retirement plans which would definitely be a much appreciated benefit by many.

review_title: Lucky to be a part of the team!
pros: I am a therapist at Seneca, and have been with the agency for just under two years. I have had several years of experience in the work force before joining Seneca, and since then, my expectations about what it could be like to work for a non-profit mental health agency have been blown out of the water! It is incredible to me that an agency as large as Seneca has managed to maintain so connected to it's mission, values, and beliefs. I am impressed by the many ways that the agency strives to grow and change according to client and community needs. My experience of staff and management here at Seneca has been phenomenal as well. I feel fully supported, inspired, professionally challenged, and truly at home as a part of this agency. In my humble opinion, anyone would be lucky to be a part of the Seneca Family of Agencies team!
cons: Work/life balance can be a challenge at times, but loving the work I do makes it worthwhile.

pros: This company offers a ton of experience in a short amount of time. It is cool place to work because most people are young and forward thinking. Fresh ideas and adaptability is welcome. The company is constantly growing and expanding; which offers new opportunities to develop professionally. The environment is open enough to speak directly to a person when there is an issue.
cons: There is not much room to grow in the educational field and the salaries are not comparable to public/charter schools. There is no tenure, union or perks to remain a classroom teacher. Education jobs are not diversified to meet the needs of the student population.

job_title: Special Education Project Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros:
Authentic - Seneca leadership embodies the philosophy of Seneca every day.  In looking for an employer, it was important to me to find one that could express their mission and values, and act in line with them on a daily basis.

Empowering - Working for Seneca, I feel valued and empowered to be the best professional I can be.  My talents are noticed, appreciated, and utilized.  My weaknesses are supported and strengthened.

Dedicated - I work for the newly established Seattle based team.  The whole team here is genuinely dedicated to our goals and outcomes.  Everyone is intelligent and hard-working, and we have the start of something really special here in WA!
cons: I have been employed since January and so far I do not have any cons - I've been treated with the utmost respect as an employee and love the work I get to do every day!

review_title: Inspiring at first, disappointing in the end
pros: Seneca's core values are amazing and the work they do is incredible.  Seneca hires the best of the best, and generally everyone is focused on the same goals of helping families.  "Supervision" is provided to work towards BBS hours.
cons: Although provided with an impressive PTO arrangement, supervisors make it very difficult to actually utilize this time for much needed breaks.  Supervisors are more concerned with productivity than they are with their staff as individuals, and tend to miss obvious signs of burnout.  Punitive actions are used to promote "growth" and "meeting goals" rather than support and balanced supervision.  For an agency that prides itself on  being "strengths based" it is rare for this to be seen in how employees are handled when they are struggling.

pros: Seneca has a beautiful mission and provides services that other agencies will not do, making it a true blessing for families with severely challenged children.
cons: Paperwork demands are absolutely unrealistic and require you to work late into the evenings and on weekends to get work done on time.  Management is over-worked and unable to value individual contributor's participation. Clinicians are encouraged to become robots doing what their supervisors want them to do as opposed to becoming solid therapists with their own individual styles.  Don't rock the boat  (express any opinion) if you ever want to be promoted....you gotta drink that kool-aid to survive.

pros: Working at Seneca has many pros such as: getting to work with really amazing families, overall staff is very friendly and dedicated to providing clients with great services. Weekly supervision is reliable and a priority within programs. Pretty good benefits including vision, dental and 5 weeks PTO (includes sick time).
cons: The job is very emotionally draining and often times supervisors are disconnected from what the work is like on the ground. Pay is low and difficult to move up to a higher position without your masters degree. Agency lacks diversity and does not have adequate training and conversations around cultural differences between providers and client's being served.

pros: You do get one on one time with kids and time to work closely with clients anf families.
cons: Clinical supervision is extremely inconsistent. You get no valuable time with upper management as they seem to be off on expensive "work trips," and driving brand new cars which seems weird for a "non profit." CEO is almost unreachable as I have never seen him in the home office the many times I have been there over the last several months. I think the management is predominantly white, yet the company preaches and prides themselves on their diversity initiatives which are outdated and lackluster.  Just seems like a lot of smoke and mirrors and I think families within the Bay Area and beyond deserve more than a company that is searching for awards and accolades (such as pressuring staff to rate highly so Seneca can earn top work place of the year). I just had such higher expectations for this company and am only staying here because I believe in what I am doing with the few clients I have contact with.

pros:
Excellent Training- I was amazed at the breadth and depth of their new employee orientation. The initial hire trainings total at 80 hours, covering client care, first aid/cpr, documentation, hands-on/restraint training, and more. 
Friendly and approachable management- from supervisors to program directors to the CEO, every single level of management was straightforward, friendly and approachable
Commitment to clients- Unconditional care. Everyone really does everything they can to provide the best care possible for everyone who uses their services.
cons: I was involved with Seneca during a merger with a residential treatment center in the North Bay. Seneca was attempting to bail out a failing agency. Seneca did an outstanding job trying to save these programs, but ultimately was unable to do so long term. My main complaints with Seneca come from the period of time where they were attempting to provide continuity of employment for the staff of this agency. The process was haphazard at best. There was some degree of transparency, but ultimately some great, longstanding employees were left without work and with little compensation and no clear reasons.

pros:
I have worked at Seneca Family of Agencies for 7 years. 

This is a great place to sharpen your skills as a clinician and be a part of team that cares about the work they do.  If you're interested in working with children and families in traditional and non-traditional settings Seneca is the place to be. I've felt very supported in my efforts to get licensed and to attain more training and education because Seneca values staff development and wants the people that work for them to be well trained and informed. They also strive to support staff's efforts to promote within the agency and will work with you if that's a goal.
cons: The work is very demanding and the pay is not great. The learning curve can be steep in some of the programs and sometimes there's not enough time given to new staff to adjust to the fast pace. The draw back to hiring within is that some of the management staff don't have the experience and the skills to effectively manage people.

pros: I have been lucky to grow as a person and professional at Seneca over the last nine years. The best part about working at Seneca is knowing that even though the work can be difficult, you have an army of committed and caring individuals led by inspiring leaders who will stand with you and do whatever it takes to make sure that the children and families we serve are successful. The opportunities for learning and growing my skill set continue and I feel truly lucky to have found my professional family with this agency.
cons: Its hard work and requires commitment and flexibility, but for those who enjoy relentlessly pursuing solutions to our communities most difficult problems, there are no better people or organization to have as your team!

review_title: Challenging work, but a great opportunity to sharpen your clinical skills and work with a dedicated staff.
job_title: Care Coordinator (Social Work) in San Francisco, CA
pros: Seneca has a "do whatever is takes" attitude when it comes to providing mental health treatment to youth and their families.  The agency prides itself on offering some of the best clinical trainingin the Bay Area.  For me, one of the greatest "perks" of working at Seneca are the employees.  Seneca tends to hire passionate, intelligent, and fun people ... which helps when managing the stress of working with at-risk youth in under-served communities.  Also, 5 weeks of paid vacation per year is hard to beat.
cons: Seneca's starting salaries are not very competitive compared to other non-profit mental health agencies in the Bay Area.  The workload can be demanding and good clinical supervision can be inconsistent.

review_title: Their heart is in the right place
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Hayward, CA
pros:
This agency has some amazing people at it's core. They all really care about the values of Seneca and the children and families they serve.
There is a lot of training available at Seneca starting with two weeks of basic training that every Seneca employee goes through before they begin their job. 
Everyone I have met at Seneca is very motivated and strives to do their best everyday.
cons: During the  time I have spent at Seneca I have felt that there has been minimal support and training specific to the role of Mental Health Counselor. I've heard that the 'job is hard' so many times from various staff that it's beginning to sound like a mantra. The job is difficult but in my experience I have found most of my difficulties have stemmed from a lack of clear expectations and training specific to my role.

pros: Seneca's values resonate throughout the organization's wide range of programs. My coworkers are some of the most dynamic and kind people I have ever met. I get to go to work every day and work for a mission that I believe in. The day-to-day work can be hard, but it can also be very rewarding.
cons: I am looking forward to seeing more diversity in the highest levels of management and leadership. Pay and benefits are comparable to other non-profit work, but it is difficult (if not impossible) to live in the Bay Area on the entry-level wages offered.

review_title: Supportive work environment; great place for personal and professional growth
pros: Seneca emphasizes staff care in a way that is very much appreciated. We work hard and collaborate to meet deadlines and provide services to the highest standard. Regular check-in meetings with supervisors and mentors help to keep staff (particularly newbies like myself) feeling supported and confident in their contribution to the agency. There's a lot to be learned, which could be overwhelming if not for the fact that this agency proactively provides channels of support and communication between staff and their supervisors/coworkers.
cons: The Washington program is still relatively new and in start-up mode, which makes for somewhat unpredictable work days. If you can roll with the punches, though, it's that much more rewarding.

review_title: Great Nonprofit in the Bay Area
pros: Over the time that I have been at Seneca, the  benefits have increased to be more directed towards self care such as discounted gym memberships, retirement, and better EOP programs. The amount and diversity of training to feel like you can always be learning more and bettering your role as a provider is exceptional at Seneca.  I feel as though in the program I work at Seneca is making a real effort to hear our feedback and create a more diverse, positive and mindful workforce. Unconditional Care Model that Seneca works from is refreshing and I admire that I work for a company that truly goes above and beyond for the children, youth and families we serve.
cons: Some of the direct staff roles at Seneca don't have the best guidelines and tend to create turn over due to burn out.   Lack of paid time off  for hourly staff.  Ability to fund-raise for programs that don't have as much funds.

review_title: An absolutely rewarding place to work
pros: I have been with Seneca for about 5 years and my overall experience here has been invaluable! I work with a great team of superstars. Team-work is essential and my team is both supportive and encouraging. I have a very approachable supervisor who has an open-door policy, gives helpful feedback, and appreciates all of our efforts. This was honestly my first real job after college and I think that my supervisor not only helps with our advancement and growth in the agency, but with self-growth as well. I think Seneca is a great stepping stone for recent graduates who would like to become teachers, clinicians, therapists, social workers, etc. Seneca is a wonderful place to gain the needed experience to be in the real world and who will also support your path into making it a real career. Seneca is a real motivational place to be. Seneca not only offers unconditional care for the clients they serve, but also with their employees.
cons: Nothing I can think of.

review_title: Youth Centered Org with a Positive Culture and Strong Values
job_title: Director of School Partnerships in Oakland, CA
pros:
- Org values are integrated within the culture and practiced/lived through the work on a daily basis 
- Very passionate, dedicated and smart staff with a positive sense of community
- Strong leadership and thoughtful decision making
- Willing to take risks and try new things to benefit the youth and families who are at the center of the work
cons:
- From a program management perspective, the work with youth, families and schools is very challenging and no matter how big your heart is, not everyone is the best fit based on the need. 
- The staff structure tends to favor specialists in mental health and education, for good reason. However, it can make it difficult for people with different types or broader bases of experience to grow professionally.

pros: Seneca has supported my professional development and allowed me to grow my skill set and explore new opportunities in a way that feels very unique and special.  Over the past five years I have been encouraged to head up new initiatives and attend training series to spur professional growth, all with the support of caring managers and EDs. I feel lucky to work in an environment that champions personal and professional development and allows people to go out on limbs and test new ideas for the betterment of the organization as a whole.
cons: There is room for improvement with compensation, although I believe that positive strides have been taken to increase wages across the board. Additionally, although six weeks paid leave is an excellent start for paid family leave/ maternity leave, it would be nice to see that expand.

review_title: An agency where "unconditional care" is seen in every interaction, every intervention, and every moment.
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros: The individuals that come to work at Seneca are the most creative, supportive, and caring people I have ever met, and I truly feel privelaged to work beside them every day.  From the training department to the support staff from other programs to my team that I work with on a daily basis, the patience, passion, and unconditional care that is shown is remarkable and astounding. I think that the employees that Seneca hires speaks volumes on the agency's values.
cons: Coming into the position and working in this field, I knew that it was going to be a challenging job. It can be difficult at times not to bring work home with you, especially when clients are going through a difficult time in their lives. With that being said, the agency and leadership really stress self-care and are great at boosting morale after a long day.

pros: My co-workers and supervisors are awesome. Seneca hires the best people. Also, for a part-time job, they provide really great benefits. When I was looking around for part-time work, there was hardly anything out there that provided benefits at all. This organization really does value its employees and that is felt from the benefits, to the extensive training they offer, to the way they try to make changes to help us maximize our time and efforts. It's a great place to work!
cons: The pay isn't the highest, but for a non-profit it's decent. And as I mentioned before, the benefits are great so I feel that makes up for a lot. Also, being that I'm in an administrative role, there aren't a lot of opportunities for growth or advancement. I'm at a place in my life where I'm okay with that, but for someone who is looking for growth, that may be a challenge.

review_title: It doesn't get better than this!
pros:
Seneca provides much needed care and support to families in need throughout California. The agency works hard to recruit bright, enthusiastic, and dedicated staff. Over time, they have recruited an amazing group of people. 
The agency strongly values training and education, supporting staff to attend trainings within and outside of the agency. It is not unusual for employees to leave to pursue graduate degrees and return a few years later in another capacity. 
Seneca works to support children through traditional avenues but is willing to think and try options outside the box as well. I have worked for Seneca as a Child Psychiatrist for more than 6 years and I imagine I will be here for many more.
I feel incredibly lucky to be doing this important work side by side with other people who have similar values and priorities.
cons: The work can be exhausting. Working with children and families who have often experienced significant trauma is really difficult at times.

pros: I loved my work at Seneca. Coworkers became good friends and it was a very supportive and healthy working environment. Seneca has a big push to make sure they are hiring the right people and a large focus on diverse staff. Pay was above most non profit wages but still low for California living.
cons: Little room to promote and move up. In an effort to be inclusive and acceptive Seneca often gets scared to talk about topics such as religion and law enforcement. I offered several times to hold trainings regarding those two topics but there was no follow through. Seneca seemed that it had good intentions but just didn’t follow through on bringing awareness and training to those issues during my employment there.

review_title: Fabulous place to train and grow professionally while working with children and families!
pros: Seneca's culture and values are apparent from your first day in basic training!  The unconditional care approach it takes with the children/families served differentiate this agency from others.  There is room for training and professional growth within the agency and the social service sector as a whole.  Seneca values working together with the family and child to form stability and success in the home, school, and community environments.
cons: As Seneca stays abreast to the many changes that occur statewide and federally in regards to mental health service delivery, this could sometimes cause quick changes in policies and procedures.  Seneca could also improve upon providing mental health services in other threshold languages.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working in their Community-Based Wraparound program for 3 years was an incredible learning experience. That provide continual training and professional development, but they also hire incredible clinicians and social worker who will teach you the true meaning of "unconditional care" for the clients you serve. Not an easy job by any stretch...but a great place to learn the craft.
cons: As mentioned before....these are not easy jobs. the Family Partners and Clinicians are generally working in all different locations (sometimes not the greatest areas and at night) but they are providing incredible support for kids and families in need. Rapid Response shifts add additional stress to an already emotionally challenging job. And the paperwork requirements are no joke!

pros:
-Encourages Unconditional Care Model to provide ongoing support to children and families.
-It's definitely one of the best non profit organizations I've worked for.
-Depending what team/program you work for, you definitely feel supported.
-They invest in ongoing professional development and there's many training opportunities
-Great place to start if you're a recent grad
-There's a variety of programs and in different locations so transferring to different programs is a plus if needed.
-Non profit takes mental health notes and documents seriously so they provide ongoing deadlines which prevents procrastination (which i've experienced in other non profits)
cons:
-Could always pay Clinicians more of course 
-Self care is incredibly important given that the work is difficult
-Lots of paperwork - however comes with working in mental health
-Support of Bilingual Clinicians and staff members needs to be enhanced; they definitely have a higher rate of burn out given extra work

job_title: TBS Clinician in San Francisco, CA
pros: Seneca employs some of the most talented and passionate mental health workers that you can find. working as a TBS Clinician provides a lot of freedom to taylor the treatment plan to what you as a professional sees fit but it is also limited in that the treatment is dictated by a lead therapist's existing treatment plan. TBS is a inventive, intensive approach to fixing a problem behaviors of youth. Theres a lot of freedom to make your own appointments and manage your own schedule. The office culture is very supportive and the co-workers collaborate well teams, programs, and cases.
cons: Often times youth and families will be over indoctrinated with services. This makes it hard sometimes to be effective when competing for time with clients against multiple other providers who are all attempting to provide similar services. Working in the field can be challenging when clients dodge you and lack engagement.

pros: I am asked all the time what I enjoy the most about Seneca and consistently my answer is that I work with the most creative, committed and passionate people who want to make a difference in our communities. Decisions are always mission and values driven so though at times there are hard decisions to be made, the right decision always emerges. Programs are innovative, the culture is dynamic and at the end of the day you know you are making a difference. The learning and growth culture of the company has really compelled my own professional development and mindset to always be seeking growth opportunities.
cons: Sometime the work with clients can be difficult and challenging, bringing up unexpected emotions, feeling hopeless or ineffective. However if you can overcome that and work through it, that is usually when the most learning and growth occurs.

review_title: I work as a Case Assistant with Seneca and have never felt more inspired and supported by my coworkers.
pros: Seneca hires incredibly compassionate and friendly people who are truly devoted to the well-being of the kids we work with. Each person I have met shows that to me. All employees, whether clinical or administrative, are required to go through a Basic Training process that really emphasizes the organization's commitment to unconditional care. I have been working here for 4 months and feel rewarded every day. So happy to have found this organization.
cons: Working with emotionally disturbed youth can be exhausting. Remember to lean on coworkers or the Employee Assistance Program for self-care. However, these kids are truly incredible and all the challenges are well-worth it.

review_title: Great philosophy and approach, but face the challenges of being a social service agency
job_title: Clinical Counseling Associate in Berkeley, CA
pros:
-their philsophy is client-centered, research based, and humanistic.
-emphasis on self-care
-promote continued education
-ability to move within the agency and be promoted
-weekly meetings with supervisors who give active listening and guidance
-ability to be creative with interventions with clients
cons:
-very low pay for challenging and sometimes dangerous work
-poor petty cash management
-mediocre benefits
-often understaffed to save the company funds which can cause client case overload
-not unionized

pros:
The staff, the kids, the families. It is such a community.. all working together to support one another and watch our clients thrive. I am part of one of the most dedicated, creative and inspiring group
of staff that could I have ever hoped for. The training and learning is ongoing and the administrative team is approachable, knowledgeable and "one of us." The teachers constantly find ways to engage and inspire our clients. In one word: COMMUNITY

Their developed pathways for further careers in unprecedented and I feel I am supported by supervisors to explore long term career goals in which Seneca encourages and supports (verbally and financially). This job has been life changing.
cons:
We are a small school, so our impact could
Always extend further than our walls. Would
Love to explore ways to do that.

review_title: I have had the honor of working with Seneca Center for seven plus years full-time.
job_title: Crisis Stabilization Counselor in San Leandro, CA
pros: During the last seven years the highlight of my experience at Seneca Center includes being able to work with children and families and provide unconditional care for them during their most difficult time. This has also helped me become a better person and learn to see outside myself and help others in my community.
cons: The unfortunate thing with working in a place where we deal with a place that gives so much, is not always seeing the fruit of our labor. It truly hurts my heart to see some of our children die in the same communities we hoped to save them from. However, I have learned that we could only plant the seed and hope that we can see our children blossom from the unconditional love and support that Seneca staff has provided for them.

pros: Seneca is an entrepreneurial, innovative, and hard-working agency who knows how to hire extraordinary staff.  While it is not always easy to work in the non-profit sector, Seneca truly values its employees and respects staff at all levels.  I have been here for three years and found staff at every level to be smart, engaged, passionate, and joyful, and these values are brought into the work we do on behalf of children, youth, and families every day.  It's a special place to work and make a difference.
cons: Seneca is currently engaged in a diversity initiative to ensure that our staff and senior management reflect the diversity of clients and families with whom we work.  We have work to do in this area, but I appreciate that this is an explicit high priority for the agency.

review_title: Gold-standard of mental health services for children and families.
pros: Seneca provides you with the training you need to be successful in working with a high-need client population. Its supervisory policies will keep you compliant with the top industry standards, and you'll develop excellent habits as a mental health worker. There are extensive opportunities for promotion and professional growth. No other child and family agency in the Bay Area has this level of organization and training.
cons: There is some resistance to using evidence-based practices within the agency. The health benefits are rather poor, and you will be required to pay a large percentage of the cost every month. Seneca salaries are less competitive when compared with other agencies.

pros: I have been able to grow so much professionally here.  I got great support for becoming a licensed clinician straight out of grad school and have had lots of opportunity for mobility and advancement.  I love the people I work with and feel very supported.  I love the youth and families we serve.
cons: Like any non-profit job it can always feel like there's more to do than time to do it.  It's easy to feel the pull to work too much and I did that early on in my career, but I learned to set better boundaries for myself and work sustainable hours, and I do feel there is support for that.

review_title: It's so much more than a job!
pros: I'm not naïve enough to think I'll ever work with more amazing people if I leave Seneca, which may be why I've been here for nine years. This is very difficult work, but the organization makes sure staff have the resources and support they need to do it well. This contrasts sharply with my previous experience in public schools! It is energizing to work with a group of like-minded individuals and it gives me the courage I need to keep doing difficult work for vulnerable students.
cons: If you're looking for jobs in education or nonprofit, you already know the downsides (salaries that don't match skills or experience, the reality of how deep children's needs can be and how poorly our social service system address these and an intensity of work that never dulls). That's not unique to Seneca, but it certainly is true.

review_title: Rewarding experience providing unconditional care to children and families in need.
pros: Working in a professional environment that puts the needs of the children first every time is a rewarding, yet exhausting experience. Senca Family of Agencies looks for employees who are willing to give more time, dedication, and heart than the average 9-5 calls for. They support their employees by providing opportunities for continuing education and training through out the year, giving one-on-one supervision on a weekly basis, and providing excellent benefits (because you'll need the PTO).
