Their selective interviewing process yields sharp, stoic, and compassionate employees that make great team members and co-workers.
cons: Burnout. Working with this population is stressful and difficult no matter how you approach it. Employees need to excel at providing their own self-care and balance if they want to avoid feeling run-down by the work. Navigating county services can often be challenging and frustrating as well.

pros: I am constantly humbled by the level of dedication and intelligence our staff bring to the table.  This is one forward-thinking bunch on a mission to support kids, their families and each other.  In my experience, supervisors are genuinely invested in their supervisees, and welcome opportunities for growth, feedback and appreciation.  Seneca provides pathways for staff to grow professionally and emotionally and find their true fit within the organization.
cons: In true non-profit fashion, many of us find ourselves trying to do more with less.  Although most of us would say its worth it, the work can be exhausting at times.

pros: As a classroom counselor, you get to work with some of the most undeserved youth in the area. The job is different every day. It is challenging and rewarding.  Seneca Family of Agencies is large enough that if one particular job is not as appealing as you may have originally hoped, there are many other various jobs available that still work with some of the most vulnerable youth in our state..
cons: Many of the youth you will be working with can be difficult at times. Some care givers and community agencies have grown tired of the youth the agency serves. Many times you find yourself fighting for the rights of the youth the agency serves. Seneca Family of Agencies is a great place to work, but it still is a Non-profit so salary/pay is not the highest.

review_title: Abundant opportunities--an agency to learn and grow with.
pros:
Seneca is not only an organization committed to providing excellent services for the youth and families they serve, but they care about each staff person. Committed to professional development, varied growth opportunities and extensive training, Seneca is a place for both seasoned and novice clinicians and counselors alike. As a long-term employee I've had the opportunity to work in numerous regions, learn several different service types/approaches, and even shift between clinical and administrative positions. 

If you're looking for an organization to support your professional growth, while maintaining excellent services for clients, Seneca is an organization you should consider.
cons: I've never been more challenged by the needs of my clients... and I love it! I have grown immensely as a clinician and I wouldn't want it any other way.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Salinas, CA
pros:
I worked at Kinship Center a member of Seneca Family of Agencies in Salinas, CA. The best part of working for Seneca is the work environment. Everyone is supportive and willing to help each other out with projects and assignments. The work is also very rewarding. 
Because Seneca is so large, there are a lot of opportunities to explore other departments and programs. Management really encourages staff to explore their interests and work on projects that you have a passion for. Management is also very good about making sure everyone feels supported and appreciated, even across the agency.  
It's a really wonderful work community to be a part of and I would recommend this agency to others.
cons: You will be asked to take on a lot of different tasks, so time management is key. Be sure you're prepared to work hard.

review_title: Great company- poor pay and benefits
pros: Seneca's mission to provide unconditional care to underserved communities is real. Seneca provides the best mental health support to our clients and families in a variety of capacities- school-based, community outpatient, intensive case management, etc. Seneca's quality of care is the absolute best in the Bay Area (in my opinion). The workplace is fun, exciting, collaborative, team-oriented, positive, and VERY challenging.
cons: Seneca pays very poorly. Starting therapists start at $43,000 which is almost unlivable in the Bay Area. Seneca offers a terrible retirement plan currently (but I hear there will be a better one rolled out in September) in which they don't match any contributions. Seneca treats their lower level employees as disposable which is why the turnover rate is so high.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Berkeley, CA
pros: Open collaboration between Supervisors and staff. Assistance and feedback to enable employees to be and feel successful. Emphasis on self care. Regular supervision and personal assessment. Transparency and communication which is rare in most jobs I have had in the past. Community and team building events. Making and seeing Impact you make in the lives of the community we serve. Great way to get your foot in the door in social work.
cons: Burn out is possible if self care is lacking. This work isn't for everyone so the turn over is high. Paperwork can be overwhelming if you procrastinate, but an important part of the work

review_title: You need to be truly in peace and compassionate to take on this role.
pros:
-Had a lot of sweet moments with team and peers.
-Enjoyed my time with the kids I worked with.  They were a silly bunch. 
-Provided thoughtful gifts to kids during the holidays.
cons:
-Had to advocate for daily breaks
-Witnessed a lot of abuse of power from staff towards clients.
- At times feedback was taken personally.
-Classroom/school conditions where very unsanitary. 
-Some days you might get kicked and punched, other days you may be spit on.
-Unfair pay 
-Admin did not have compassion for workers
-Not enough POC is higher level roles
- There were a lot of trainings available, but due to the challenge of the work, there were rarely opportunities to attend trainings. 
-Witnessed lack of communication between staff, admin and parents.

review_title: Good opportunity to learn and take elsewhere
pros: Very supportive of additional training through stipend, flexible regarding schedule, trauma informed care is talked about, helping community
cons:
Unprofessionalism among leadership; nepotism instead of qualifications; lots of ethical issues and hypocrisy with standard of care. 

After a couple years here I began to voice my concerns over culturally informed and trauma informed care and was considered difficult by doing so. Feedback is not welcome despite what they preach. Trauma informed in practice is not honored often. Leadership is cliquey and often inauthentic in favor of bottom lines.

pros: The PTO is generous, they offer great maternity leave options, healthcare benefits and training opportunities. Additionally there are many growth opportunities within the organization, and management encourages exploration and learning of different areas within the field/ non-profit world. There are endless trainings and professional development for all levels of staff.
cons: As with most non profits the compensation is on the lower end, however the knowledge and experience gained supersedes pay in the long term.  Working in medical is challenging, fast paced and a lot to keep up with on a daily basis. Paperwork can be overwhelming and a lot to stay on top of per medical requirements.

review_title: Great mission, but management and staff support depends on the program
pros: The vision and mission of the agency are great. The staff they recruit are young, eager, and supportive of each other. There are a lot of opportunities to learn and receive training. There are several different programs that you can work and move laterally to learn different things.
cons: Program-specific. Some programs have very young management and frequent turnover, so feeling consistently supported is challenging. Poor work-life balance. Management has a hard time "practicing what they preach" where they expect too much from staff and fail to model the agency mission values they strive for.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Sweden, ME
pros: The people who work at Seneca are truly wonderful individuals. I loved working there because every one is so supportive of each other. The pay wasnt half bad and they were good at giving a raise when you went above and beyond or have been there for 6 mo. I left making 15.23.
cons: This place is a thinly veiled child brainwashing facility where they scrub behaviors from the minds of the clients and replace them with more socially acceptable behavior and stability. Think like the Cryo-prison from the the movie "Demolition man." Then the nature of the job can be nightmarish and you WILL get hurt there. You gotta have thick skin and a heart of gold to be here longer than 4 years.

pros: Seneca's commitment to supporting their employees is something I have found to be a truly unique experience, not only peer-to-peer support, but from management and above. It is very helpful in the work that we do to have a solid foundation of support in order to offer the same support to our client's. My experience working at Seneca has been such that even on days I might not want to go to work, I still look forward to the end of my day when I feel I have contributed something to the lives of our families and fellow employees.
cons: Work/life balance can be difficult to maintain when working within Seneca's "Unconditional Care Model." This dilemma is an active conversation within the agency, and although discussed, is often easier said than done to manage.

pros:
5 week PTO
$500 clinician stipend 
Training opportunities 
Supportive colleagues
cons:
Unrealistic expectations 
No work-life balance due to the above 
Always are asked for feedback - but feedback is never taken positively and instead is looked at as “complaining”
All about numbers/quantity vs. quality 
Feedback is never taken 
Clinicians burnt out
Directors and upper management are unapproachable (say they are but have cold demeanor)
Lack of morale

review_title: Seneca is a wonderful place to work!
pros: I have worked for Seneca Family of Agencies since 2000. It is an amazing place to work. I started out as an unlicensed clinician, and am now a clinical supervisor. I have received quality training in behavioral, relational and ecological work, and advanced training in family therapy and motivational interviewing. And once I became a leader, I received supportive and informative leadership training as well.
cons: Really I cannot think of any cons! While difficulties arise all the time, Seneca fosters a culture of being open to feedback so I have always felt able to share my perspective and to therefore help solve difficult problems.

review_title: Good values needs better follow through
pros: The company as a whole provides some really amazing services to a lot of families struggling through difficult times.  The direct care staff is generally made up of really caring and dedicated people and their passion really shows through their work.  Some supervisors and upper management are very open to feedback and working with you.
cons: Admin positions have a high turn over and the way your feedback is taken and considered really depends on your location and supervisor.  Clique culture and nepotism  play a role unfortunately and for a non-profit that provides really awesome services,  sometimes the negative underhanded office culture really dampens the feelings of support the company claims to provide.

review_title: Amazing Mission and Values - Great Place to Grow
pros: I love working for Seneca because of the unconditional care and commitment to children and families. Even though I work behind the scenes (not in a direct care role) I feel like I am contributing to an amazing mission and culture. The support of the leadership and professional development is better than what I have experienced in other companies. Everyone here is wonderful to work with - hardworking, collaborative, open to feedback and compassionate.
cons: Folks who work here are extremely passionate and dedicated, and out of that motivation work really hard. I think it can be easy for some to burn out, but if you are aware of this, and set your personal boundaries, it's can be managed. Seneca is generous with their PTO offering and encourages staff to take time off when needed.

review_title: Well intention-ed agency, but regularly miss their cultural goals
pros: Flexible hours, no ego with supervisors, very understanding staff
cons: High turnover, very low pay, very expensive health benefits, little to no growth opportunities - unless you are rich, one cannot afford to make a living in the Bay Area, with what Seneca provides as a salary.

review_title: It was a very transformative experience for me.
job_title: Senior Mental Health Counselor in Fremont, CA
pros: Great team at my site. I loved the admins and all the collaborative effort between Seneca and the school staff. We were pretty much allowed to do whatever we needed to for the kids. The kids were trying most times but I loved all of them. It was so great to see them mature and move on.
cons: Lots of changes suddenly. Not that much transparency when it comes to admin from higher up. I really have to thank our director at our program because she was really honest with us and without her, we might really have been left in the dark. Low pay for very demanding work. After unbundling, it felt as if we were always working to make our minutes quota instead of providing care for the kids.

review_title: They Truly Care About Employees and Clients
pros: I love working at Seneca because they are constantly seeking to do better for their employees and their clients. The culture (giving feedback, accepting differences, seeking to do better, etc.) is so strong, that it spills over into how you view the world.
cons:
As most of the other reviews say, the starting salary for bachelors level can be difficult to live on in the Bay Area. They have increased it over the past couple of years though, and the pay actually seems to be comparable or slightly better than other nonprofit or government jobs in the area. 

Everyone has a very full workload, and at times it can be unrealistically full.

job_title: Clinical Supervisor in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Supports and values staff
Opportunity for professional development
Strong values around social justice
Strong advocacy for clients
Values cultural diversity
Supportive of staff who are parents
6 weeks of vacation per year
cons: The clinical work is very challenging. In many cases, clients are suffering from severe trauma as well as depression, anxiety and drug/alcohol addiction. Most clients are affected by poverty and have had long histories with child welfare and criminal justice system. Seneca staff have the added burden of interfacing with these systems (probation, public education and child welfare) that tend to be less progressive and clinical in their approaches to working with children and families and resistant to change.

review_title: A non-profit rooted in Unconditional Care
pros: At Seneca you will be surrounded by people who are mission-driven and care deeply about the children and families we serve. As a Seneca employee you will grow immensely as a professional through training, supervision, and collaboration. If you're looking to scale up your impact and make a real difference in the lives of undeserved children and families, Seneca is a great choice.
cons: Seneca does some of the  most challenging (but essential) work in the public sector. The work can be stressful and chaotic, and can be hard to leave behind at the end of the day. Also, as is common in the non-profit world, compensation does not always match the importance of a role.

job_title: Director of School Partnerships in Oakland, CA
pros: Over the past 10 years, Seneca has invested a great deal in me. They supported me in getting licensed, developing the skills that are important to me, and building leadership abilities. I have had fantastic supervisors that have helped me grow both professionally and personally. The children and families have taught me so much as well about perseverance, resilience, and what authentic support looks like in this work.
cons: This work is challenging! We work with kids and families who have experienced significant trauma, and some display very challenging behaviors. This work is definitely not for everyone, but if you are passionate about supporting folks and communities in need, you will love this job.

pros: I love working at Seneca. I recently read an article in the magazine from my alma mater on their efforts to create a culture of inclusivity and found myself thinking about how grateful I am to work for an agency that focuses on this, both for staff and families served.  Seneca has clear values of unconditional care and everyday I am a part of putting this into action and the tireless work of always wanting to do this better.  Seneca is an agency that is willing to challenge itself and invest in looking at what is going well and where we can improve.
cons: As with all social service organizations, filled with passionate people, work life balance is a struggle!

review_title: Challenging and rewarding work, supportive coworkers
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Berkeley, CA
pros: I look forward to coming to work almost every day.  In addition to being engaging and fun, the work feels meaningful and worthwhile.  I enjoy being part of a team.  My coworkers and supervisors are great people and professionals that I respect and admire.  I feel supported in my professional development.  My more senior coworkers provide guidance and advice in my day-to-day work, and I also have the opportunity to attend agency trainings.
cons: Working with children with behavioral and emotional difficulties is draining and can leave me with less energy to pursue personal interests outside of work.  Paperwork is an unpleasant but seemingly necessary part of the job.

pros: Generally, the staff are amazing. People are friendly, personable, and are there because they believe in the mission statement. You will definitely find friends for life.
cons: Unrealistic work expectations for low pay. No real chance for professional development in non-direct care roles. Agency perpetuates elitist models within social work. Management in desperate need of cross-cultural supervision training. It's a toss up whether you have an awesome supervisor or not. Baseline requirement is a bachelor's degree (even for entry-level, or facilities type positions) effectively cutting out qualified and passionate candidates with practical skills and knowledge.

pros: The organization lives up to its mission of unconditional care. Staff think outside the box to come up with creative interventions that will better serve each individual client, and management supports and encourages innovative thinking from both non-direct and direct-care staff. The work is meaningful and rewarding, the staff are fantastic and extremely supportive, and direct, open feedback is encouraged.  Employees participate in ongoing trainings and weekly supervisions to foster professional growth, and there is room for movement and growth within the organization.
cons: The work can be difficult and demanding - there is a lot to do in a limited amount of time, and there are sometimes emotional challenges - which can make the days feel long and can carry over into personal life.

pros: Everyone who works here genuinely wants to be here and has a passion for helping children & families.  There are regular trainings to keep employees up to date on current practices, and scholarship opportunities to pursue higher education. There are also opportunities to move to different programs throughout the agency and explore different career options.
cons: Although the work is incredibly rewarding, it can also be challenging and there is high turnover.  Also, there is no retirement plan.

review_title: Good experience, but would not recommend to a friend.
pros: Working with compassionate, empathetic people. The general, basic training served as a good reminder for my motivations of working in the field.
cons: Too stressful for very little pay. Working in community-based programs has you working at any hour of the day. I knew this going in, but it's difficult once you're doing it. The work overall was not good for my health. Also, the paperwork is impossible to keep up with on top of the stressful situations.

job_title: Education Specialist in San Jose, CA
pros: Seneca provides healthy budgets for their partners to work with, and was always willing to pitch in to help a partner organization in difficult times.  Offers mileage reimbursement, meal reimbursement, and helps employees pay for college.  Good PTO for teachers.
cons: Many managers are allowed to run free and are not accountable to anyone.  Often times the wrong people are in positions of authority, and can ruin partnerships.  Pay is very poor for the industry, and managers had no experience in areas they were assigned to manage.  Very cultish.

pros: Working with like minded people, who all want to support youth and families in need is inspiring.  Co-workers become best friends and youth and families are the best teachers I've ever had.  There's many opportunities for diverse experiences and mobility within the large agency.
cons: It is a fast paced work environment because we are always on the cutting edge of how to best support youth and families in crisis.  That can be stressful at times and it's easy to work to hard if you're not very self aware.  There is support from supervisors, peers, and agency policy to take of yourself.

pros: I honestly couldn't find a better place to work! Seneca Family of Agencies works on a model of unconditional care for not only the students, families, and communities we serve, but for the employees too. I feel like my personal and professional growth is nurtured in this organization. There is also so much support, camaraderie, and a sense of family among my coworkers! I feel challenged and fulfilled in my work here at Seneca.
cons: I can't really think of any major negatives thus far.. other than not having a larger presence across the country.

review_title: Great people doing important work with heart
pros: I have worked for Seneca for 15 years in many different roles.  I have stayed because I love the work, the clients and families are wonderful people and I have learned so much from them.  I also love the people I work with who have so much respect for our clients and bring a lot of heart to their work.  It's a great place to work.  Because I have two small children I also really value the family friendliness.
cons: The work is very fast paced and challenging the clients are always put first.  It's hard work often and though I enjoy the challenge it's hard for some people to manage.

pros: The staff at Seneca are across-the-board high caliber and positive collaborators. People genuinely care about the mission of the organization and it comes through.  There is a strong work ethic, people work hard, and good ideas are noticed.  There are many different pathways to advancement within the agency and it is encouraged to build skills in different positions.  Professional development is encouraged and supported.
cons: Seneca does tend to favor those who take the initiative and are willing to go the extra mile, so if this doesn't describe you, it might not be the best fit.

review_title: Have worked for Seneca over 5 years.
pros: Under my supervisors/ directors I experienced personal and professional growth, received 2 promotions and am always engaged in continuous training.  Staff bring fun, joy and curiosity as well as personal interests that are dynamic and engaging.
cons: At times depending on the program there can be frequent turn over and instability in supervisors especially when it is a new program that is being built (which can be expected.)

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Anaheim Hills, CA
pros: Working with Seneca has been a mind expanding experience. I have seen myself grow exponentially in my understanding of psychology, time management, organizational skills and ability to work with diverse groups of people. I feel like Seneca as an agency cares about me as an employee and cares about my personal growth and career development. Working for Seneca, I know that I am doing impactful work to help grow and heal underprivileged communities.
cons: Working for a mental health agency can be challenging in the amount of bureaucracy and red tape that we deal with. Someday it feels like we spend all of our time writing notes, filing paper work and dealing with incompatibilities with the county.

job_title: Manager of Operations in San Francisco, CA
pros:
My Seneca story is different than most, but one that I definitely want to share.  When I applied for a position at Seneca four years ago, I was (of course) looking for a position in a company that would match my values, skills, and interests, and that would lead me into a career where I could thrive and develop professionally.  
However, my primary goal was to find a company that offered same-sex partner benefits, and immediate medical benefits (instead of the three-month waiting period that seemed to be the policy for so many others).  My partner was undergoing chemotherapy and radiation treatments, and was losing her health insurance midway through the recommended treatment schedule.  Seneca was the first company I found that respected same-sex partnerships in California (keep in mind, this was four years ago), and valued their employees enough to provide immediate health care benefits.  When I think of Seneca's "unconditional care," I know that it applies to more than just our Seneca clients.  It applies to us, our families, our team members, and all of the communities we serve.
cons: I am going to be honest, the hiring process is selective.  For my first position at Seneca, I had a group interview, an individual interview, and an interactive interview.  The position I was applying for was very competitive (it was an administrative position at Building Blocks), but I was really impressed by how Seneca was able to individualize my application process despite the amount of applicants they were considering.  My three interviews were scheduled quickly and conveniently, and I walked away knowing that I dearly wanted to be part of this organization.  I was struck by the people I met, and the passion they felt for their work.  I was so honored when I was offered the position, and I continue to feel honored and humbled to be part of the Seneca team.

pros: I have worked for Seneca Family of Agencies for 8 years and have loved the forward thinking, open to change and growth mindset of the leadership. I am proud to be a part of an organization that is always trying to improve and is able to think outside of the box. I have never been stifled in my thinking or action and remain challenged on a daily basis!
cons: Working for Seneca Family of Agencies is an intense experience and it remains an ongoing struggle for me to balance the amount of work commitments required with my personal life.

review_title: A work place that feels like family
job_title: Community Partnership Coordinator in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Collaborative group of employees who know they can lean on one another
- Self care is a focus of any position you acquire within Seneca
- A work place where feedback is not only accepted but encouraged
- New and relevant trainings are always an options for the staff to grow and learn
cons:
- Locating helpful resources can be tough because of the circumstances many of our youth and families are under
- There can be times when the work can take a toll on you but only for the best reasons possible

review_title: Caring, motivated people working for a great cause
pros: Everyone is truly motivated to be there. Promotions are mostly from within, so supervisors know what clinicians are going through. There is a lot of flexibility and awareness of staff lives outside the office.
cons: As any social work nonprofit, the pay is low compared to the demands of the work. Supervisors do not get a lot of professional development, and can be hit or miss, even when they are clearly motivated and care about their work.

review_title: A very unique opportunity to serve and be part of an amazing community.
pros: It is a gift to work with such caring and dedicated people who not only support Seneca clients but also encourage and stand by each other. The staff are highly motivated, well-intentioned, and do not give up when the going gets tough. Working for Seneca also provides great opportunities for personal and professional growth.
cons: Working in a social services agency like Seneca requires the ability to hear--and respond to-- many stories of trauma, grief and loss. While successes are quite rewarding, it can be tough to balance empathy and compassion with one's own emotional limitations.

pros: Pretty good benefits, 4 weeks PTO minimum for employees, great job for folks looking to be a clinician or SPED teacher, hard but rewarding work, possibility for very close connections with the team you work with
cons: low pay for the Bay Area, very stressful job with vicarious trauma, people working in home office get higher pay than those in direct service, Seneca seems to reward education over experience

review_title: Happy to be working with an Agency that supports and serves families in our Community !
job_title: Southern Cailfornia Family Recruiter in Tustin, CA
pros: The Pros- Working for Seneca Center has been very exciting and rewarding. Seneca is a growing agency helping families through the most difficult times of their lives. I can see the positive growth with our Foster , Adoptive families and Children we place in the placement programs. Support Groups, Training and educating is just one of our goals.
cons: Cons- Not at this time. I feel I can work through anything with the support that Seneca Center provides.

review_title: The Mission Statement aligns with my belief which is to assist families in need
job_title: Wraparound Parent Partner in Tustin, CA
pros: A recruiting team hires the top talents, who are crucial for each modern organization. With top talents the agency would survive.  Working in teams brings sources of innovation, managing challenging projects and delivering results.
cons: The company offers good benefits; flexibility; Co-workers naturally fitting in, making my working responsibilities easier and effective. .

review_title: Caring company that is out to help our most "at risk" kids and families.
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Anaheim Hills, CA
pros: This company has been very welcoming and caring since I started less then a year ago. They strive to keep the entire staff team united and working together by doing events such as "staff appreciation" days and a holiday party. Self care days are encouraged, upper management do not micro manage, and you feel really appreciated here. They also offer an amazing opportunity to receive your MSW through USC with an awesome scholarship opportunity.
cons: I've heard there is not much room for raises or bonuses.

review_title: Seneca is AMAZING--Best work experience so far
job_title: Family Support Counselor in San Jose, CA
pros: Seneca Family of Agencies cultivates a very safe space for all of their employees and clients served. Seneca does an exceptional job of training all new hires (2 week orientation prior to starting at your program-specific location) to provide you with a deeper understanding of the mission, vision, values, ethics, etc. They require First Aid and CPR training, and it's all built into the 2 week orientation. They have a nurse available for employees. Excellent medical, dental, vision, chiropractic, and mental health services. Seneca is very thorough and they take care of their employees. Weekly 1:1 and group supervision is provided. Supervisors are also almost always available, and if it's after hours and you're on an on-call shift, then there's the Rapid Response Team who is incredibly supportive and acts as an interim supervisor (and communicates this with your supervisor later). Seneca offers ample CEUs and other professional development opportunities. Although I did not take advantage of this, but Seneca recently partnered with USC's online MSW program so that you can continue working at Seneca (and you'll still get paid and it'll double up as your required internship program), and have some (if not all) of your tuition covered. Seneca is truly an amazing place to work because of the supervisors, the co-workers, the opportunities to move up the career ladder, the work, the mileage reimbursement, the clients, and their family members. Only reason why I left is because I went to an out-of-state MSW program. Seneca was everything I was looking for and more. I am a much better person and social worker now because of them. Thank you Seneca!
cons: There is a high turnover rate at Seneca. I personally did not feel burnt out because I really optimized my supervision time, but a lot of my colleagues were exhausted and disliked being on-call. Although I didn't mind it, others might, so I thought it would be important to note that I had about 5 supervisors in the over a year time I spent working at Seneca. The supervisor turn over was due to promotions, personal leave, pursued higher education, and more (though I always had the Rapid Response Team if I needed someone). Pay is not great especially for the amount of work you do--if you speak Spanish or Vietnamese and you're able to pass the language test then you'll receive a pay increase. A lot of my colleagues felt as though they fell behind with the progress notes policy (completing notes within 24 hours of client interaction) in our wraparound program. Again, on-call can be exhausting (when I was there it was 24 hour shifts 3 times per month), especially if you worked a full-shift and get called out overnight (you do receive a stipend for that though). Although the orientation to Seneca is excellent, the job-specific training occurred way too late (I had worked at Seneca for 3 months before the conducted their formal wraparound training). By that time, I felt like I was thrown in without any training, and then when I got the training, it was validating that my work was on point, but that sink or swim style was not good. I was lucky I had a few other people from the 2-week orientation start with me in the wraparound program.

review_title: Difficult job, but lots of professional growth.
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Fremont, CA
pros:
+ Challenging work environment
+ close-knit atmosphere with coworkers
+Many opportunity for professional development, including training courses.
+The joys of seeing a client transition to their next stage is rewarding.
cons:
+There is a lot of talk about self-care but it was difficult to implement a self-care system when there seemed to be so much work.
+Paper work was exhausting.
+The burn-out rate among employees was staggering.

pros: My site has a very supportive staff from the top down and we all work very well together. As a site, we are a cohesive group. There is a disconnect between us and headquarters and a stronger presence would be helpful to increase morale and knowledge of our site.
cons: Pay is pretty low but it's a great agency! It would be hard to stay for long unless you're in the SF Bay Area and are an LMFT. I am sadly already looking for other employers because I don't make a livable wage.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros: My management team was able to support me until I grew confident in the roll I had and was able to successfully guide a new team into place. They are understanding of the need to take time off and support self care.
cons: The job is very difficult and you are exposed to a lot of secondary trauma. The system for care of these kids is flawed and though I understand Seneca operates from within a flawed system, they could do more to financially support their staff.

pros:
Great team, great trainings, surrounded by people who really care and are advocating for children who, often times, have no one in their corner. 

Lots of PTO, understanding when your mental health is being compromised, and supervisors want you to have a work/life balance, however, the reality of achieving such is difficult when the performance expectation is so high.
cons: Lots of paperwork (to be expected working for a nonprofit). Working with outside agencies (social workers, lawyers) can often times be very frustrating; although, there is always someone on your team to process your experience with.

pros: Office culture is definite a big one, I can honestly say that the nicest most compassionate and friendly people work at Seneca. People who work here definitely want to help youth and do their best to make sure that happens. Since this can be very hard work , they definitely do emphasize the importance of self-care and taking time off.
cons: work-life balance can be very difficult, we are working with families who need a lot of support. Pay is not that great and unless you have a Master's Degree there is very little opportunity for growth

pros: I have worked at Seneca for 7 years and it has been a wonderful place to grow and learn new skills. I have been supported to tackle new challenges and take on new responsibilities in a variety of roles. I really appreciate how Seneca views professional development and I feel lucky to work at an organization that invests so much in its employees.
cons: There are so many arms within the organization, it's sometimes challenging to stay connected to all of our programs. That said, it does seem like efforts have been taken to connect us all to each other more fully and more regularly.

pros: In my experience across multiple Seneca FOA programs, it's striking how the Mission and Values of the agency are present in the day-to-day operations. I feel blessed to work for an agency with which my values are aligned and in which the values are actually central to the programs and services provided.
cons: I have experienced some inconsistency with individual managers regarding their approach to programmatic growth, at times seeming to favor growth (quantity) over quality. Overall, I think  the management team holds quality of services provided to a very high standard.

pros: Seneca is the most supportive, collaborative, innovative, mission-driven organization I have ever had the pleasure to work for. The employee benefits, open lines of communication, and opportunity for advancement (both with educational opportunities and within the organization itself) are unprecedented. I applied for this job not really knowing what to expect, and I am now convinced that accepting this position was the best professional decision I have ever made.
cons: It is virtually impossible for a nonprofit to provide a living, entry-level wage in California - but Seneca does what it can with its available resources.

review_title: You can feel proud of your work at the end of your day or shift, but it's often hard, draining work.
pros:
I've worked with more people (colleagues) in this agency than I can count, and I don't think I could count a single one of them as a less-than-great person. The people Seneca hires are incredible, inspiring folks who support you when you need it the most.

The company values not giving up - trying your best, again and again, and trying one more time just in case. I think this is really cool.

Once you've invested your time in the work and agency, your opportunities to move around and seek promotions increase greatly.

The clientele will always present a challenge to you, but their breakthrough moments are some of the most beautiful moments I've witnessed in my life - professional or otherwise - because you know just how much work they did to get there.

It would be hard to forget a job like Seneca, even if your time in the Agency is brief. Its impact is lasting.
cons: It's very difficult work that doesn't pay what it's worth, but it should pay your bills. Balancing life and work has been very difficult - especially when having a bad day, or week, or month. It's very important to have a vibrant, healthy and fun life outside of work, because burnout is a real thing that can carry over to life outside of work. The benefits package used to be really good, but is more expensive now with less flexibility (although I haven't had problems with their recently exclusive provider, Kaiser).

review_title: Everyday I have had the opportunity as well as the need to grow. And everyday I have felt limited in my capacity.
job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Berkeley, CA
pros:
Coworkers: Seneca draws a crop of really warm hearted and unique people, so the tender times are invaluable and affirming, and in times of disagreement I already knew that people's hearts were in the right places so it makes fixing problems easier. Additionally, working with people who are either naturally or trained to be emotionally attuned and somewhat more actively in touch with their feelings makes communication during those times more peaceful and productive. 

Bosses: Accessibility is a plus. My bosses have been and remain available to support in my actual position as well as to discuss concerns, frustrations, and ideas for growth and progress. There is also a sincere attempt made to understand what is happening at the ground level and what can be done to address issues that may seem small from a bird's eye view, but insurmountable on the ground level. This is made more possible because both of my bosses have spent in the positions that they now supervise/direct, which I think is a great call. Additionally, there is a genuine push for camaraderie within smaller teams as well as larger programs, making the job itself more enjoyable, if on some days, only "off the clock". Both of my bosses have spent in the positions that they now supervise/direct.

Clients: They are wonderful. Make me want to pull my hair out sometimes, AND they are some of my favorite people. Some of them are really funny, others exceptionally kind, all gifted in some way, however corroded by life circumstances any gift might be. THIS IS A HARD JOB, make no mistake. Often, it is difficult to remember how fantastic these human beings are until they in their best context. But it speaks to their ability to endear folks to them that even when they so often act like royal you-know-what's, I still love them. To varying degrees, certainly, but really love them all.

Values: Seneca does care about words like love, kindness, forgiveness, communication, respect, honest, curiosity, etc. It comes in different packages, but there is an actual commitment to make the ideals of the company action words.
cons:
There are not at all enough people of color or people from low income backgrounds working with a population of students and families that are primarily of color and from low income backgrounds. The chasm between these cultures (mostly black and working class families having to work white and middle class people) is evident in the a large percent of interactions. There are just cultural misunderstandings that do not work in the favor of the families and clients we work with because the power dynamic is already skewed and in support of white people with money and the ideals embedded in white middle class culture. The families and students deserve to work with people who will probably have an easier time empathizing and working effectively as a cultural insider rather than good hearted middle class and/or white folk who are in many small, large and all together important ways, cultural outsiders and telling of their incompetency.

Teams are great, but when integral positions are held by incompetent people (I am not even trying to be mean, just accurate from my perspective) it creates a serious problem. Too often I have had to do the job of two people because the teacher does not know how to prepare for, run, or teach a class. This has been at multiple sites. I do believe that if the teacher is unable to effectively do their job, we are missing the point of being in a school setting. The main issue is the amount of time an incompetent teacher is able to keep disservicing students, which may not be up to Seneca in a public school setting, but is a serious impediment to providing quality services. Accountability for teachers is key.

pros: Good work/life balance (comes and goes), benefits are good compared to other agencies, the services provided to clients are excellent
cons:
Some program directors seem like they're not being held to any standard at all. They are just phased into a position because they were a manager or assistant director at the time their predecessor left. They weren't effective as AD and are even less so as director while other more competent managers leave the department or agency b/c they aren't being compensated and appreciated enough.

To this day, the QA director is quite disconnected, uninformed, and unresponsive (unless it's to reply with a "thank you" email). She's not supportive of staff and actually rather suspicious, asking other people to hesitantly spy and report back due to a lack of trust. Seneca is about open, honest communication, but it's not being modeled in this case. It's an open secret and a morale killer.

I've heard numerous instances of people being offered a position (and even accepting) only to be told later the offer has been rescinded b/c they need to interview other candidates. SO RUDE!

It was nice when QA was a reliable department.

pros:
-The people who work at Seneca are hard-working, dedicated, and kind. They are doing their best in a very tough field with limited resources.
-Depending on your department and how it's structured, there's some flexibility in working hours and remote work opportunities.
-Decent benefits for a nonprofit, generous PTO.
-Lots of professional development opportunities for client-facing staff.
cons:
-Very high turnover, enough to hold a new employee orientation every two weeks.
-Demanding workload and low pay.
-Lack of communication between departments and programs.
-Most upper management has been promoted from within. Not inherently a bad thing, but there is little innovation or improvement because things continue to be done they way they always have been.
-Next to no professional development for administrative staff, nor opportunities for growth or promotion. Administrative staff are encouraged to move into clinical roles.
-Very little accountability for performance.
-The content of New Employee Orientation is geared toward client-facing staff. The most disturbing and traumatic cases from Seneca's history are examined  in great detail. It felt exploitative and there was no forewarning that this kind of content would be discussed. Employees are pressured to share intimate details from their lives. It felt like a two week long therapy session. Lots of people cried at one point or another. I took little away from NEO that actually applied to my work although it gave me great insight into the culture at Seneca.

review_title: Good place to work if you are hungry for work experience.
pros: The company has a laid back culture with maximum focus on serving clients. My manager only cared about my working getting done not how I got it done, which I appreciated. I worked with a lot of people my age, which was a huge plus.
cons: Depending on which location you work for, and who you are reporting to, it can either be a thankless place to work at or you'll have a good experience. Executive management seems corrupt. Serious lack of communication and transparency. In my department there was no room for growth.

review_title: Seneca's core value is unconditional care, and its employees work tirelessly to see this value brought to fruition.
job_title: Special Education Teacher in Fremont, CA
pros:
I've been employed by Seneca as a counselor and teacher for the past five years, and I have had some of the most powerful and moving experiences of my life in this job. I've seen children reconnect with parents and once-distant family members. I've seen students with trauma histories overcome learning disabilities to learn to read, and I've seen them find joy in a book. I've seen students give inspiring graduation speeches, and I've been fortunate enough to give graduation speech for some inspiring students. I've watched kids see snow for the first time, and I've been a target for their first snowballs. I've been yelled at, and I've been told, "Thank you." I've redefined my understanding of "patience", and I've seen the difference it has made in my own life. 

Working at Seneca has also been an incredibly challenging experience, but the support I've received as an employee is unprecedented. I've learned the meaning of professionalism and self-care. I feel fortunate to work in an environment where feedback (both positive and critical) is not only accepted, but required. I've had numerous opportunities for growth over the last five years, which has given me a chance to examine and focus my career goals. Support from my supervisors and inspiration from the children keeps me motivated and interested each day, but my perseverance over the last half-decade is due to the amazing people I have had a chance to work alongside. My coworkers, past and present, are the strongest and kindest people I have ever met, and I've shared both the most challenging and the most amazing experiences of my life with them.
cons: As a Seneca employee, you put your life into the work. This level of dedication can and will lead staff to experience moments of overwhelming joy and laughter as well as moments of heartbreak and frustration. The work is not easy, and it is not the right job for everyone. However, our children need empathizers to role-model coping skills and teach healthy methods for dealing with negative feelings, and sometimes these difficult experiences provide the greatest learning opportunities for both youth and staff.

review_title: Great place to work with tons of mobility, opportunities and a chance to be creative and give feedback.
pros: Seneca Family of Agencies fosters an environment where creativity and independent thinking is strongly encouraged. The Intensive Case Management program is fairly new and there are plenty of kinks to work out, but so far the flexibility I have been able to enjoy in my schedule and how I interact with the kids has been a great experience. I feel very supported by my supervisor and coworkers and really appreciate all of the opportunities I have had for growth and developing new skills.
cons: At first it was difficult coming out of Basic Training into Intensive Case Management (ICM), as the sense of comradery was no where to be found. Being in a community-based program can be lonely at times as we are always out in the community and have different cases and therefore cannot bond over shared interactions with the kids. The team is pretty boundaried and it almost felt at first as though it was taboo to talk about our personal lives and really get to know each other. Also, being a new program, ICM does not really have a concrete structure with procedures to follow and new employees feel lost and bored in their first few months as they develop a case load and figure out their own rhythm.

job_title: Family Support Counselor in Oakland, CA
pros: I have been employed with this agency for 6 years and I have not one complaint.  They choose their staff with pride and the way staff bonds with each other is awesome.  The work we do is satisfying knowing that you are helping kids and their family in the most difficult times in their lives.  The bond that we create with clients and their families are amazing.  Not too mention, the agency have the best supervisors and directors that one can ask for.  They listen to you and support you with anything and does not make you feel like you are bothering them.  Seneca is high on making sure their workers are not burnt out, encouraging taking time off for self care just because you need it and will not give you any issues around it.  This agency is very flexible with your shift with most programs within.  They offer the most amazing support to our families and clients, including 24 hour crisis line for added support.  My experience with this agency has been fabulous.  The training at this agency is above remarkable.  They make sure you have all the knowledge to do your job in the most therapeutic manner possible.  There are yearly trainings to keep staff refreshed.  You are also appreciated with staff bonding outings which endorses bonds with each other and appreciations for all the hard work that we do. Seneca is the right choice.
cons: The only cons that I would say is that the salary can be higher for the type of work we do and that there need to be some kind of retirement program for the employees, hopefully with the agency matching our monies.

review_title: As an employee for the past 6+ years I am proud to be a part of such a wonderful organization.
pros:
Seneca is a great agency committed to providing strength and stability for children and families in need.  Their “system of care” ideology, providing a continuum of services to address the complex needs of the children and families we serve, is well supported by their espoused values modeled throughout the agency and embraced by all.  I have been part of the recent merger as Kinship Center was embraced and developed into Seneca’s innovative organization. It’s wonderful to be supported by such a great agency with a forward vision placed on the development and growth needed to assist its staff and clients in the best way possible. 

I have been well supported by my current Supervisor and allowed the opportunity to be creative, self-reliant, and trusted to get my work done with little micro management; a great work style that is important in gaining value and mutual respect. I appreciate my Supervisor and Director’s supportive efforts in providing ongoing training in evidenced based practices. I’m looking forward to more agency growth in the future as a result of their ability to target and build in areas of need.
cons: I have little room for complaints about the agency, staff, or office culture. It’s all great. However, I feel due to the overall county mental health requirements sometimes the paperwork constraints complicate our ability to provide increased care to our clients; greater focus is placed on completion of paperwork and could be spent differently. It also impacts daily schedules and makes for very long days. This is nothing to do with the agency, just part of the work we do and the field we work in. Unfortunately, it’s the least appealing and  challenging part of the job.

pros:
AMAZING support -- this was my first therapist/clinician position, and was nervous about working in this field. Seneca has some very knowledgeable clinical supervisors who are willing to support you in any way possible. I have felt supported by co-workers as well, and the environment is just so warm and friendly. Despite the job being difficult (come on... any mental health job can be difficult), you can always count on someone willing to assist you in any way possible. 

TRAININGS -- Seneca does an amazing job of offering a multitude of trainings on various topics. These trainings have definitely helped in my professional growth!

Appreciations -- Yes, I feel very appreciated as an employee here. Seneca prides themselves in making each other feel appreciated from the very moment you begin training. This does, in fact, translate into the work you do... and you do feel appreciated by everyone (from directors to managers to staff!).

Overall, depending on the site that you're at... this may look different, and the experience may be different. From my experience, management does a good job making sure we're doing ok, always offer support when needed, and really make the staff feel valued. I can't speak for every program, but I've definitely enjoyed working here thus far.
cons:
Pay is DECENT -- I'll admit, the pay has gotten a little better than when I first started here, but I feel like the compensation is still a little low for the amount of work that we do (e.g. Caseload, paperwork, meetings, etc). I'm hoping this can be addressed, and that staff can be compensated for the hard work that we do.

High turnover -- I've been with the agency for a few years, and have noticed that a lot of the people that I started with are all gone. Might be the pay? Might be the burnout? I'm not sure... but the agency needs to do a better job of addressing this if they don't want to be known as a "stepping stone" for people jump-starting their careers. 

Burnout -- Yes... it's real. Although the agency supports staff to utilize PTO, if you don't take care of yourself, you'll experience stress and burnout. Mind you, the overwhelming amount of paperwork/notes don't help with feel stressed. I'll add a caveat though... paperwork/notes are manageable if you plan accordingly!!

review_title: Do not work for Seneca WA.
pros: Working with the youth was empowering. I was able to see that despite the everyday challenges, teaching is something that is still a joy. Seneca  CA is way more organized though the compensation is less in CA than for Seneca WA.
cons: For Seneca WA: Horrible upper management. They are into promoting only those who kiss up and not those who truly have the purpose to be with the company. They do not live their mission. Code of ethics was violated tremendously with no consequences to upper management and subordinate staff involved. Do not work for this company if you are in WA. The work environment is dangerous and there isn't much protection for teachers if they are assaulted by aggressive students.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: The children and clients are the only good thing about Seneca.
cons: Before you take a job at Seneca Family of Agencies in the bay area consider these things. If you're a recent graduate, if this is your first real job, Seneca has a ridiculous policy that does not allow recommendations. What does this mean? If you were to put down your supervisor on a job application which most applications this day ask for the only thing they can say is confirm your dates of employment. I didn't find this out until almost a year into employment. You would think they would mention this upon hire, they don't. You are also required to do a mandatory two week training that is only relevant to direct care staff. If you are admin don't expect to get anything out of the training except for maybe two days of it. A few supervisors play into the power dynamic role and will keep you down as far as professional growth goes. Internal applications (ie changing roles) have to be approved by supervisors if they're not you can still apply but hr will reach out to supervisors and ask why they didn't approve and they can give their advice and ultimately be a big part in deciding whether you can move on or not. Supervisors can be highly sensitive and quick to call you unprofessional or hostile for not answering them the way they like. Do one thing wrong you're defined by it do one thing right it doesn't matter. Lack of appreciation for staff is real with some supervisors if they feel it's what you should be doing they don't think you deserve appreciation. Turnover is extremely high and being short staffed throughout programs is the norm. No one ever answers as to why these things are so. The whole team including a supervisor left within six months at First Stop. There is a problem with management/director at this program and many others that fails to be addressed. Hiring process is "take what they can get". They will give you some bs stat saying you were in the top 90th percentile of all these fictitious people who applied. Untrue. You were just the only people who applied and they were desperate to hire and fill roles. You will be stretched extremely thin doing other job duties in order to support where the company is lacking. Underpaid for all the hats you have to wear. If life happens and you need support from Seneca as a company or your supervisor don't expect much. They just like to say they're a company who supports it's employees but that isn't true. The company likes to promote diversity and no tolerance for discrimination but 80% of the company is white. When you have an experience of discrimination within your program your supervisor will do whatever for the client; client first employee last. It also doesn't help that all of the clients are people of color who can't get the help they need because 80% of the company is white and doesn't understand the struggles they are going through because they can't comprehend or understand it. All they do is feel bad for the client. See through the facade, think long and hard before taking that job. You don't need that unnecessary stress in your life. Level up, keep job hunting, a good opportunity will come.

review_title: Teams would be great if we actually got to collaborate more
pros: Most of the staff overall are young so there's a young vibe and openness to ideas and diversity, all staff monthly meetings it was cool for ppl to get acknowledged and welcome the new employees. You could feel the camaraderie. Great supervisor and team meetings. Not bad pay for the position especially is not licensed but would be nice for more.
cons: Not clicking with some co workers as too busy so it can feel a bit isolating, the paperwork (avatar) the most annoying system for those who are familiar making notes and other paperwork stressful

pros:
I thought that when I started my job at Seneca a little over a year ago that I would pass through and onto a different career in higher education very quickly.  It wasn’t long after being here a few short weeks that I realized that it was the best fit for a last lasting career.  I am supported by my supervisors at every turn and consistently encouraged to participate in professional development to make me a better educator, counselor, and professional.  Seneca rocks! 

Kelley Student Support Assistant All-in!
cons: I can not think of any!

review_title: Social work is broken but this is one of the better organizations
pros:
This is a very organized non-profit and generally, folks treat each other well. 

In a job like this, you'll hear heartbreaking stories of child abuse and neglect, you'll tackle mounds of state required paperwork, you'll meet kids you'll never forget, and you'll be giving more than you ever have at any other job. All this will make you proud. 

You'll bond with your coworkers. When you work with SED kids, you can't help but form strong friendships with your coworkers or at least respect some part of them since they do this job. 

Sometimes you'll be hanging out with kids & just enjoy the fun.

It is certainly an opportunity for personal growth. Having never done or needed any kind of social services, this opened my eyes to the day-to-day life of children borne from chaos, anger, and neglect and the overstretched system designed to house, clothe, feed, care for, & educate. 

The hours are actually kinda cool if you work residential. They do longer, fewer workdays.  

If you express interest to the right person there could be a more positions available to you. Since there's a high turnover rate in this field this means you can shift jobs a bit easier.
cons:
This is tiring work. No, exhausting. The turnover is pretty high and people seem to move on to totally different careers.

Typical in this line of work, if you're a residential or school counselor, you need to fill out paperwork every day. It can be like homework since many times it doesn't fit into the regular workday.  The other part typical for the industry is that those on the front lines who have the hardest jobs are paid the least. They're usually understaffed so doing something like calling in sick, if you catch them on the wrong day, can yield a bitter response.  

There are two types who tend to work here: optimistic college-educated people who don't know much about how social services work (this was me) and people who have seen it all before because they grew up in or around it. The latter tend to bond more seamlessly with the kids while the former tend to gravitate towards the administrative duties. These are, of course, generalities, but hopefully helpful in giving you some of the atmospheric flavor.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Hayward, CA
pros:
The work is important, and the kids you get to work with are incredible, funny, and stimulating. Most of your co-workers and team mates in direct care are wonderful warm  and like-minded people. Everyone has good intentions and want to have fun and help the kids. 

The benefits are very good, I love having kaiser, and my dental and vision is taken everywhere I want to go. 

Management attempts to make you feel "heard" and communicates with you fairly directly, giving lots of feedback. 

At Seneca you have a lot of opportunities to shine by taking on special projects, contributing extra, etc. which can be great career development for new graduates.
cons:
Many of the teachers in classroom sites are not Seneca teachers, and can be awful to work with or downright oppositional and resent the fact that there are Seneca staff in their classrooms; this is not all teachers, but some. Because they are not Seneca, they don't adhere to the same models or standards. '

The pay is dismal for living in the Bay Area

The organization is scaling too quickly; there aren't enough people to provide coverage. Workers always feel spread to thin, and there are increasingly large paperwork requirements. Whether it be due to numbers and making the organization look better, or simple scaling problems, there seems to be a push to transition students before they are ready; sometimes it feels that it is more about the money than the kids.

Although they've tried to make a culture surrounding change and giving feedback, especially to higher-ups, they don't actually want you to give feedback. I know of several Seneca employees who have received critical feedback for communicating their suggestions or feedback to higher-ups. 

Seneca makes a big fuss over training and education opportunities, but with the documentation requirements and lack of coverage, it is impossible to take advantage of these opportunities.

Some departments of Seneca have a ton of funding and are getting amazing perks like access to company cars, while others are left in the dust and having nothing to offer the kids to work from, and all the while are told that "there's no money"

If you are not firm in setting limits, Seneca will take over your life. Supervisors etc. will ask you to take part in special project and do extra work but not compensate you extra; taking overtime is harshly discouraged for hourly workers. All the while, Seneca espouses the importance of "self-care" to avoid burn out.

review_title: Upward Mobility and Decent Pay for the Few
pros:
Seneca provides programs that are a great help to children and families across CA and now WA. If you want to work for an organization that does good work, Seneca accomplishes that. 

Seneca does a very good job of hiring great people. I have definitely made some wonderful friends there.
cons:
There are a select few who are paid well at Seneca, the majority of them are white, and from the same prestigious university. These people, making well into the six figures, will often tell employees making $30-$40k that everyone suffers financially to do the good work because that's the nature of working in a nonprofit. I've seen them say these things in casual conversation as well as meetings/new employee training. That attempt to be empathetic to the majority of their employees' financial distress is disingenuous and harmful, and the turn-over the organization experiences parallels the outrageousness of that claim. 

Seneca has money, but it spends it on expanding its programs - often at the expense of pre-existing programs that are already understaffed and underfunded. By the time I left, Seneca was coming up with a roll-out of higher pay for clinicians. That's great, but it still lags behind several other nonprofits and pales in comparison to what a clinician can be paid at a county position. 

Seneca talks often of race and diversity, but when it comes to management positions at headquarters, POC staff are passed over for new hires. Seneca is the type of place that will hold weekly Diversity and Inclusion events to discuss the lack of POC in management, and then when it's time to fill a new managerial role, look outside current POC employees and hire a white person. 

I believe that Seneca cares about the pay of their employees, and issues with diversity. However, when it comes down to making big changes, Seneca is very slow and ineffective, and incorrectly assumes that people should sacrifice some of their own well-being for its mission.

These are two big problems with Seneca, but there are many others, including life-work balance. If you can't set a firm boundary, Seneca will take over your life, and as romantic as that can sound as a nonprofit clinician/director/manager the reality is pretty bleak.

Seneca can be a great stepping-stone, but for most it's not a place to build your career - whether that be because you'll continually be passed over, or you literally can't afford to stay.

pros: Seneca puts a lot of time and resources into training its employees. Going through the initial 2-week training, I was very impressed by the time dedicated to teaching new staff about the history, philosophy, and culture of the agency. My initial impression is that this is an agency filled with very hard working, dedicated, and engaged employees. Everyone I have met and worked with in my brief time has been extremely welcoming, supportive, and helpful.
cons: It appears that finding work/life balance is a thing to watch out for.

review_title: Good agency, but an agency nonetheless
pros: Really good culture (may be program dependent), high-mid range pay for non-profit, great room to explore different roles, programs, etc. and super career oriented. Really good and reasonable insurance and amazing vacation(pto).
cons: Super high burnout/vicarious trauma intensive work. Like any non-profit pay is not the greatest. Huge agency, many pluses to this, but also comes with challenges, bureaucracy, and an interested and sometimes disconnected feeling culture.

job_title: Academic Intervention Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: I love working with Seneca because my experience and ideas are valued.  I am treated as an expert and a professional with skills and assets to contribute to a common focus.  All inclusive education is paramount to the work that is being done in my area, and new an innovative ways to approach that are appreciated and fostered.
cons: As with any start-up, everyday is a new mystery! As Seneca is getting started in Washington, there is a large need, and that means a lot of travel to different partners.

pros: The relationships with the kids can be incredibly rewarding.  This is a hard job, and they try to be upfront about it.  However, Seneca could do so much more to support their employees.
cons:
There was little to no training involved, even some simple therapy techniques would have been helpful.  Our two week training involved learning how to safely restrain a child and talking about our feelings.  I ended up teaching myself counseling skills, but it was a brutal first 6 months there.  I was hired as a "floater" which meant I was traveling to a different site each day, never being able to be consistent in the kids' lives.  Because of this, I was the target of many of the kids' attacks and unsupported by staff who also didn't know me well.  When I was finally placed in one site, I was similarly dropped in with no support.  I went to the emergency room twice from being attacked by students and had to have the entire locking system replaced on my car (about $500 worth) because I was targeted by one student. 
Seneca was a great lesson in how to advocate and protect myself.  Unfortunately, I don't feel like it best served the students or the staff.  The staff are mostly all kids fresh out of undergrad with no formal training.  The kids, who need older and more experienced clinicians, are not getting the services they deserve.

review_title: Workplace culture depends which office you're employed at.
pros: Met many great and kind individuals during orientation who were employed at schools.
cons: Minimal to no people of color in the executive office despite preaching about diversity, equity, and inclusion during week-long orientation. Long-term and higher up employees displayed micro-aggressions to new employees who were poc- heavy surveillance, push to assimilate to corporate culture, and disregarded with a hand wave and "Psh, I'll get it right someday" when asked to pronounce my name correctly. Employees began treating me with more kindness when they found out that I put in my two weeks.

review_title: 5 years with SFA and  I'm still growing professionally and personally here
job_title: Speech-Language Pathologist in San Leandro, CA
pros: As the only salaried speech-langauge pathologist working at three of the non-public school that combine therapeutic and educational services, I have been very fortunate to be surrounded by coworkers (of all levels of experience) that are truly receptive and eager to learn how to better support students communication challenges better both in and out of the classroom. I have the freedom and flexibility to provide speech services in a variety of ways that are unique to each student that incorporate my own creativite and fun-loving spirit. It has been tremendously meaningful to have the unfailing support of the a team of administrative supervisors that have always encouraged good self-care and professional development through classes and weekly supervision meetings. With my supervisor's encouragement, I have taken on new roles such as facilitating agency/site wide professional development opportunities and piloting a social-emotional regulation for our youngest classroom. Additionally, I have experienced several major trials in my personal life during my employment here, and each time I have received a wealth of  genuine care and support from within the agency. Between all three sites that I serve, I certainly feel respected and valued, which only helps me to love on our students more. My time here has really been a win-win.
cons:
- The semi-high turn over rate of students and staff make carryover of services a bit challenging.
- Parent involvement is something I am still trying to increase.
- Our recent overhaul of the benefits package was a bit anxiety inducing, but ultimately did not change much for me.

review_title: SFA promotes a dynamic and supportive environment, invested in its staff, the young people we serve and their families.
pros:
Seneca Family of Agencies(SFA) aims to provide our young people and families with a different experience, where they are cared for, supported and given respect. SFA provides continuous learning to the staff and offers a variety of opportunities for advancement within the different programs. Systems are in place in order to support us in having a safe venue to discuss our work with our young people, challenges and successes, with the end goal of providing the best care possible.

SFA tries to stay ahead of the curb (trends, legislation etc.) and encourages creative thinking within the teams in order to help our young people and their families experience success. The approach to the work collectively, while bringing our own indivdual styles and diverse ideas, are some of the reasons why SFA is a place where one can thrive, both professionally and personally.
cons:
I have seen my share of staff turn-over. I feel that while it is important for our young people to learn that change is constant and it's okay for people to move on and do other things, we as an agency can do a better job of retaining our talent for a longer period of time, The benefit can be two-fold: more consistent support from experienced staff and better training transition between outgoing and incoming staff. 
The work itself is fulfilling and attracts same-hearted people. It this leads to having some make working at SFA a career. However, when we teach our staff about taking care of yourself before taking care of others, in order to best do this work, what comes to mind are the lack of retirement benefits for those who have chosen this as a career.

review_title: Wonderful mission, great for collecting hours, super organized non-profit
pros: When I graduated from grad school, I was looking for a position that offered a fair wage and opportunities to collect hours toward my licensure.  I have found this and more with Seneca; specifically, excellent training (both within the agency and through community collaborations), very good benefits (5 weeks paid vacation, medical, dental, other pre-tax deferment options), room for variety and growth (tons of programs to diversify your skills), and the benefit of being surrounded by individuals that genuinely care for the youth and families with whom we work.  I also have had some really amazing moments with the youths and families that I have worked with, which has been a bonus.
cons: The specific service that I work for is short-term, behaviorally focused, and supplementary to primary therapy, which can sometimes feel limiting in terms of the range of interventions that I can employ.  As a counterpoint, I have had the chance to work with or receive supervision from at least one very experienced clinician which was helpful in developing my personal style and approach to this work.  In general, the population that we serve can be challenging; some have had negative experiences with mental health in the past and are weary or hesitant to engage in services.  If you are not okay with spending a significant amount of treatment establishing engagement, this is probably not the best place for you to work (do private practice instead.)

review_title: Appealing mission, but I question the sincerity
pros: 4/5 weeks PTO, flexibility in work schedule (community based), challenging and nuanced work, great training opportunities
cons: I want to be fair in this review, so I will start out by saying that I recognize the experience I've had at my site may not be reflective of the agency as a whole. I find management to be extremely numbers oriented which greatly detracts from the morale of the staff. I understand that in order to run a business, there's a bottom line. However, you're employing passionate, caring individuals who got into this work for a cause, not analytically-minded individuals better suited for business.  Also, as an employee of color I often feel like I am looked to as the vessel of information around cultural considerations in the work. I haven't experienced a sense of urgency from my site's management team around staff or the managers themselves becoming invested in the more ecological side of the work (i.e. all the "isms").
